Black body, fast disappearing brown head. Aroma has molasses, roasted malt, smoke and some chocolate. Flavour tends to lean bit sweeter than the aroma. This brings some nice depth out. Or its just wrming a little bit. Quite nice and enjoyable.

Bottle. Deep black. Almost no head. Dark burned deep aroma, some woods. Taste full of dark flavours: coffee, liqourice and chocolate, black cherries. Heavenly balance. Whisky and full dark chocolate come out best towards the end. Smooth, low carbons, oily. Full bodied and drinkable, tasty, strong and deep as night. Love it.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Bottle 33 cl. Pours black with brown fast vanishing head and a kind of smokey scent. Smooth smokey and wood taste right at the start. This continues with some good chocolate, licorice, coffee and roasted notes. Very smooth and easy drinkable. Maybe could use some more body. But still quite the good beer which goes damn easy down.

Almost black, dark brown colour, head goes to the sides but stays on quite long time. Lots of lacing sticks to the glass too. Aroma has wood, coffee, red berries, theres some whiskey too and after warming up, the chocolate pops up. Taste is sweet with chocolate, coffee and red berries. Full oily texture and low carbonation. Pretty good brew.

Thats nicely black and oily, ring of lacing. Sweet licorice, coffee, dark malty bread, syrup, raisins. Oily, soft, dark roasted, sweet and bitter, long roasted finish, medium body. Nice one, well-done in all aspects!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2014 Bottle. Pours dark brown, pretty much black with a rather small, but long lasting, mocha-colored head. Aroma is chocolate, some strong dark fruit, liquorice. Taste is roasted, some liquorice, some oak, dark fruitiness. Turns rather unpleasant wooden on the finish. Fairly full, smooth, low carbonation, oily.

24/X/14 - 33cl bottle from Bierhalle Deconinck (Vichte) @ home - BB: IX/2016 (2014-1245) Thanks to Erwin for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark brown to black beer, small aery beige head, little stable, bit adhesive. aroma: very cheesy, dried figs, caramel, whisky notes, bit sweet, cocoa powder, dark chocolate. MF: ok carbon, medium body. taste: bit sourish (carbon?), slightly peated, smoky, very roasted, bitter, cocoa powder. Aftertaste: little peated, hoppy, caramel, mocha, coffee.

I tought it a was a scotch ale at first sight. Everything on the bottle invites you to anticipate an enjoyable scotch ale from its home land. Once poured, the head disapears completly leaving a soft lace on the glass. The aroma is quite interresting on this:mostly alcool and chocolate. Not much of the wood that you expect from a 12 years old barreeled. The mouthfeel is liquid but woody. Not my cup of tea but I had it with a magnificent stew wich matched perfectly this old ale kind of beer. Cheers!
Poured deep dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roast malt, sweet berries, peat. Full body, flavour as the aroma, smooth and smokey.

Sampled @ Finest Spirits and Beer Convention Bochum 2014: Sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit sehr wenig beigem Schaum. Geruch kräftig röstmalzig, Kaffee, leicht holzig. Geschmack torfig, Karamell, Schokolade, reife Früchte.

It pour a dark brown with an light brown fine head that doesnt stay long.
The aroma for me is fresh cut grass with caramel and chocolate notes.
The taste is sweet with a alcoholic kick.The mouthfeel full and creamy with fizzy carbonation.
Overall a deliciously smooth beer.
"more licorice and dark fruit than smoke. another good beer, but just under its older compatriots in my humble opinion. one day...a vertical tasting of them all!"

Bottle @ home. BBF 2015-05. Dark brown and dark reddish color and a small beige head.Nose has a delicate roast character with lots of milk chocolate and vinous raisins & plums, vanilla and oak and some peat. Taste has lots of red fruits, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, vinous raisins, dark bread, some warming alcohol. Finnish has peat, earth, nuts and some oak and whiskey. Balanced bitterness.
Bottle. Pours dark brown to black with fine light brown head. Aroma is chocolate, whiskey, wood, nuts, clove. Taste is roasty, malty with chocolate, nuts, alcohol. Very smooth.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Pitch black pour with a small tight khaki head. Deep dark red pit fruit. Rotted vegetation. Charred celery hearts. Prunes. Vegemite. Desiccated cherry cordials. Very rich and peaty. Have had this in the bottle before. The draft version (and I do not think it is the cask version) opens up a bit more. Maybe less refined but feels nicely broader. The Old Engine Oil is playing quite well with the barrel notes. Smooth finish. Cannot wait to try the older variations!

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2014 Old Engine Oil matured on Scottish 12-year Highland Park barrels, sold in a thrilling vintage series. Thin, unstable, light beige head, very dark brown colour, hazy. Powerful old aroma of old madera, dry sherry, soy sauce, caramel, candied dates, dried plums, a fair amount of peated whisky covering it all, some cherries, caramel... Complex taste of candied fruits and caramel malts, chocolatey too, strong dry and old sherry character, smoky like the base beer, complex finish with warming alcohol and a clear and somewhat dominant, but not disturbing, warming and not astringent peated whisky character. Lovely, complex, vinous and woody old ale, especially if you are into the best of Scottish single malts; I had other whisky barrel aged beers before in which the whisky was quite obnoxious and overpowering the beer, but though very much present in aroma and taste, in this case it is so elegant and refined that it only adds complexity to an already excellent old ale.  Fascinating and probably good for ageing a long time as well.  Love the aristocratic, old school bottle as well.

Bottle. Pours black with quite small head that doesnt last long. Dark chocolate, roastiness and whisky notes in nose. Full-bodied, chocolate, some coffee, good but balanced sweetness. A little bit of noble, warming alcohol. Very nice.
Bottle from The real ale store. Pours black, aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, whisky, has the same. Very easy to drink.
Dark black, no head. Aroma reminds me of port and for some reason also an animal shop. Taste is a mixture of stout and whisky. Medium body.

Bottle No. 45787. Feb. 2012. Swietny wyrob. Destylowana 12 letnia Whisky Highland Park oddala temu piwu nieco karmelowego posmagu kandyzowanego brazowego cukru a takze nieco smolistego aromatu. Dymnosci, grilowego dymu oraz wedonej szynki. Wszystko doskonale zbalansowane i uzupelniajace sie. Piana niewielka do sredniej gora wielkosci, ale nie o to w tym piwie chodzilo. To stare Ale jest czarne niczym zuzyty olej samochodowy, rozgrzana smola i posmak wedzonego drewna. Beczkowy aromat zbozowy jest tak wyrazny ze mozna chlonac go nosem do upadlego. Kolejny swietny klasyk od Harviestoun Brewery..

beige head disappears quickly without lacing. coffee coloured. aroma is smokey, leather, boozy, bit vanilla and coco. taste is smokey, leather, boozy, whisky, bit sweet, candysugar, aftertaste bitter from roasted malts. medium body and carbonation. very nice balance and rather complex.  bottle 33 cl / bd aug-2013 / bottle no 01635

Draft. Black with a thin tan head. Aroma is milk chocolate, cocoa powder and smoked peat. Taste adds some soy sauce, caramel, marshmallow and wood. Thin sticky mouthfeel. Incredibly complex and delicious.
Pours a black colour with a nice beige head, some chocloate in the aroma, the taste is bitter with some whisky coming through, with a bitter finish.

Bottle at home. Pours a very dark brown with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of dark fruits and some chocolate. Rich maltiness to it. Fantastic beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown color with cream-coloured head. Aroma of ripe dark fruit and slightly smoked. Taste is full and has mainly in the aftertaste smoky tones. Chocolate, coffee and ripe plums.

Bottle: &nbsp Thanks Matt! &nbsp Soft sweet prune, touch of roast and ash, but lots of tobacco. &nbsp Soft chocolate and coffee. &nbsp Light head and Lacing. &nbsp Lingering tobacco and print roastiness. &nbsp Nice stuff.

Bottle from Highland Park distillery. Pours a jet black with a light brown head which hangs about for a while. Unique aromas of heather peat, chocolate and a mild whisky. Lovely taste with chocolate, peaty whisky and a slight sticky prune. Amazingly drinkable for an 8%! Nice.

Bottle at an Ola Dubh "vertical bottle share. Pours a very dark brown color. Nose is lightly woody and roasty, with some caramel in there. Taste is also quite roasty with a lot of wood coming off, and is very smooth. Even better than the base.

the aroma is caramel and fruity with notes of port... the taste of caramel, dark fruits and strong wine with shades of licorice, black currant, toast and whiskey... sweet fruity and warming aftertaste... its wonderful...
Bottle. Black color with a thin foamy beige head. Aroma of licorice, peat, smoke and roasted malt. Sweet taste with a medium bitter finish.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

DWG; Pours black with a short lived tan head. Intense nose of roasted malt, caramel, smoke, dark, dried, ripe fruits, alchol, sweets, yeast, oak, coffee, chocolate, smoke and licorice. Taste is moderate to heavy sweet, umami and light bitter, chocolate and coffe lasting finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to creamy, carbonation is flat. 
Revised rating -from cask version, drunk 1th of Aug.
Bottle. Black With a minimal lightbrown head. Aroma of smoke, roastd mald, dark fruit and chocolate. Light bitter,medium sweet With not the best smoke/roasted end. Late night
Bottle from Booths, Ilkley. A thick oily black beer with rich creamy chocolate and whisky flavours, vanilla and currant notes with smokey oak and liquorice on the warming tart red fruity finish.

33cl bottle thanks to ruigo. Color is dark brown. Head is thin. Body is mild, thin to medium, medium carbonated. Taste is light sweet, medium bitter. Aroma is wood, chocolate, roasted, light alcohol, water.
Bottle. Peat, whisky, smoke, sweetness, black treacle, sweet, smoke. Good stuff
Good for a British beer. Some sweet mollasses, oak, and whiskey are the dominant flavors but for 8% is does come across watery and bland as is the British way.

Poured a very dep black with a medium head full of whiskey notes. Very light whispy head. Dark dark malts in the mouth with a slight hint of the whiskey. As the glass warms up, the whiskey becomes too much on a hot summer night. Much more a winter beer.

Appearance: Dark brown/black with thin beige head.
Aroma: Wood, peat, whisky note, treacle, malty.
Taste: Low bitter and sourness, low/medium sweetness.
Palate: Fairly thick smooth texture, medium body, low/average carbonation, fairly dry, abrupt malty, treacly, savoury, smokiness in the finish.
Comments: Good.

Plus une Scotch Ale. Une belle robe noire opaque presque sans col développant de fortes senteurs de whisky, de vanille, de malts rôtis complexes, un pointe de boisé. Quasi sans amertume. En bouche, la gorgée assez aqueuse offre des saveurs de caramel boisé, fort liquoreux, fort doux sur le lacté, lavoine, le cacao (grain sur la langue). En finale, je reste avec les arômes de whisky tourbé et boisé surets. Bravo: lassemblage de malts rend cette bière super bien équilibrée. Un délice!
bottle, this is interesting, it is dangerously approachable, the drinkability increases after every sip, Sweet and roastyness mixed with that trademark highland park scotch flavors.

330 ml bottle from STLWill - thanks again, Will! September 2007 vintage, bottle 19501. Pours a deep, opaque brown with a small beige head. Notes of very rich chocolate and fudge, vanilla, soy, peat, oak, leather, and earth. Peaty finish, which lingers. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a rich, smoky, semi-sweet mouthfeel. Sweeter on the nose. I liked this more than anticipated, and get the idea Id like other versions and newer vintages better. Definitely coming back to this series.

@ twisted kilt NYC. Pours dark black. Aroma was a bit weak but had some malt and whiskey. Taste was the same but I was expecting bolder flavors. Been waiting some time to try this and was a bit disappointed.
Piana szybko opada, kolor ciemnobrązowy, nieprzejrzysty. W aromacie ciemne słody i wyraźny smak beczki - dębowe nuty. Lekka kwaskowość od ciemnych słodów. Zostawia w posmaku lekko słone odczucie.
Bottle at home. Pours black, aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, whisky, taste has more of the same, sweet, dry.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2014 Bouteille. La Cervoise 91 . Robe opaque noir pétrole , absence de mousse. Ça sent bon la liqueur , la cerise noire, le pruneau et le malt grillé. Attaque légère puis on est vite rattrapé par une amertume persistante, des notes éparses de cerises confites , de pruneaux et une explosion de café et de malt torréfié . Belle longueur en bouche , le vieillissement en fut de whisky infuse agréablement à cette bière ses notes délicates de fruits noirs et finalement on ny retrouve peu de chêne et de tourbe. Bière plate , corps aqueux très fluide. Une élégante stout, légère et bien typée.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Flaske, 33 cl. Fremtræder flad og fedladen, sort-brun med et minimalt beige skum. I næsen: Tørrede mørke frugter, lakrids, whiskey-noter, træ. Blød, rund, lidt alkohol. Ikke så kompleks som forventet, fremstår faktisk lidt en-dimensionel med fokus på de ristede, lakridsede noter. Harmløs, men OK..

330 ml bottle into snifter, no bottle dating. Pours pitch black color with a 1 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big caramel, chocolate, toast, brown sugar, roast, raisin, fig, brown bread, molasses, vanilla, oak, tobacco, leather, peat smoke, and roast/oak earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt and whisky cask notes; with great strength. Taste of big caramel, chocolate, roasted malt, toast, raisin, fig, dark bread, molasses, vanilla, oak, peat smoke, tobacco, leather, and roast/oak earthiness. Slight roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, chocolate, roast, toast, dark bread, raisin, fig, tobacco, leather, vanilla, oak, peat smoke, and roast/oak earthiness on the finish for a white. Very nice complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and whisky cask flavors; with a nice balance of the oak character with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a smooth, moderately slick, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent old ale. All around great complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and whisky cask flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle, 33cL. Home. A pitch black beer with brown hues on the top. Small head with a poor persistence. Few bubbles. Fruity aroma (prune), smoke, wood, ashes and whisky (oh yes). Medium bitter dominated by a sugary powerful sweetness. Full body, furry texture, soft carbonation, beautiful woody bittersweet finish. Overall, great discovery : gorgeous aroma, good palate. Whisky aroma is really surprising !

Poured from a Feb 2010 bottle into a snifter darkest of brown some very light head.
Aroma of prunes raisins some booze. 
Flavor is confirmation of the aroma but with smoky chocolate. 
More carbonated than previous Ola Dubh brews consumed. Excellent.

Poured from a Feb 2010 bottle. Aroma is brown sugar booze and dark fruits. Appearance is black as old engine oil with a small tan head. Taste is brown sugar dark fruits smoke and some booze. Palate is good overall excellent.

Bottled sample from Bushwakkers in a Regina. Black in colour. Minimal head. Very boozy tasting. Quite liked this

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(07.05.2014 - butelka) Nieprzejrzyście czarne, piana skąpa, redukuje się do prawie zera. Zapach intensywny, praliny likier czekoladowy, wiśnie, świerze drewno. W samaku lekka kwaśność od słodów, przyjemnie rozgrzewający alkohol, czeokolada i praliny, czuć beczke. Goryczka intensywna, przyjemna. Wysycenie minimalne. Aksamitne w fakturze
Smooth (butterscotch), very malty with a pleasant mouthfeel + vainilla + caramel. Sweetness prevalence over alcohol. Smoky, I would say even more...Tobacco! GREAT BEER!

Aroma is sweet deep malts, caramel and sweeksweet cask woods. Taste is a rich maltiness with notes of caramel, fig and some pleasant smokiness. The Highland Park cask contributions are very pleasant. A very good fusion of beer amd scotch characters. Appearance is black with a thin beige head that retains fairly.

Poor is the deep black with very thin tan head . Aroma of sweet whiskey, grass, molases and roasted malts. Tastes of a very sweet light yet thick stout with roasted malts there is however a background of light whiskey that complement it nicely. Mouth feel is nice thick and full with low carbonation . Probably one of the better aged stout with whiskey whereas the whiskey is not as over powering as it usually is

Dark brown color with a medium head. Aromas : peaty, smoke, earthy, leaves, Pu Er tea, salt. Flavors: peaty, Pu Er tea, earthy. Couleur brune foncée, moyen col de mousse. Arômes de tourbe, fumé, terreux, feuilles mortes, Thé Pu Er, sel. Saveurs de tourbe, terre et Thé Pu Er.

Bottle at The Dean Swift, London on 26 April 2014. Poured an oily black, with a thin tan head. Seriously smoky aroma, with notes of leather and dark chocolate. Thick, syrupy mouth feel. Flavours of cured meat, whisky and dark malt. Finish was medium sweet, with alcohol soaked dark fruit, port and peat.

Bottle 0,33. First feeling in nose: is it whisky bottle? Dark brown colour, almost no head. Aroma is malty, whisky. Taste: grainy, malty, burnt earth, ash, little caramel and again whisky. Huge amazement - brilliant!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2014 What a beer! The closest to whisky Ive ever tasted. Aroma: peat, earth, salt. Taste: silky, salty, sweetish, peaty. Just whisky flavour. It is pleasant to taste but not really drinkable. Some sweetness is lacking for me. Overall very interesting and surprising beer.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Bottle #60303. Bottled July 2011. Pours black to red, sticky with a small head, aroma of wood, whiskey, deep, flavor of wood, whiskey, chocolate, coffee, sweet and tasty, medium to full bodied.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, wood, caramel, smoke. Taste is a bit sweet with dry, whisky and vanilla finish. Medium-low carbonation. Full body. Thick and smooth on palate. Good beer.

0,33L bottle, BB 05.2015. Pours very dark brown with tan head. The head doesnt stay. Aroma is dark chocolate, roast, vanilla. Taste: sweet, malt, smoke, caramel, and chocolate. Finish is smoke bitterness and some alcohol burn. Overall: sweeter than I expected, but still very nice brew; very drinkable for ABV.

Smell is wood, whiskey, vanilla appearance is pitch black with no head, taste is wood, smoke. Good beer that I thought was going to be really sweet from the smell but was pleasantly surprised by the smoky taste.
Bottle thanks to sarkynortherner. Black colour no head. Aroma is dark fruits wood ,smoke. Taste is similar slight whiskey notes little alcohol warmth. Great stuff. Bottle February 2012.

Barwa: ciemna, pod światło, brązowa. Piana jasno beżowa, niezbyt obfita, drobno pęcherzykowa, szybko opadająca, ale ładnie oblepiająca szkło. Wysycenie niskie. 

Aromat: aksamitny, waniliowy, kokosowy z łagodną nutą alkoholową. Dopiero później wyczuwalna jakby melasa i kawa. 

Smak: delikatniejszy od enginea. Nieco większa słodycz, ale również opiekane nuty, przypieczony karmel i wyraźny posmak whisky. Do tego alkoholowa, nieco rozgrzewająca końcówka.

Botella de 33 cl en el lúpulo. Mayo de 2013. Botella numero 54290 de julio de 2011. Gran asociación de harviestoun y highland park whisky. Color negro intenso con espuma oscura. Cuerpo medio con 8 vol fáciles de beber. Aromas y sabores a maderas y whisky presentes y bastante refinados. Maltas tostadas y ligeros sabores dulces. Muy buena para repetir sin problemas.

Pours almost black, with thin tan head. Rich aroma of whiskey, malts, and wood. Taste is like a mixture of good porter, smoke, and whiskey. An excellent beer, but very expensive ($15.95 for a twelve ounce bottle). Thumbs way up.
Pour a dark black coffee like color. Aroma is roasted malts, dried fruit, and caramel. Taste is as the aroma precedes. Amazing beer. Like liquid gold.

Aroma: sweet dried fruit, ripe plums, caramels. Appearance: dark brown/black, no head. Taste: medium to heavy sweet. Palate: heavy body, note of dried fruits, dark berries, whiskey. Overall: amazing beer, perfect for whiskey lovers. Bottle from Beer Hawk, England.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks zvikar. Bottle #60303. Bottled July 2011. Black with tan head. Rich aroma, chocolate and a little soy. Umami, malty and a little wood taste. Smooth, no carbonation, full-bodied, a little wooden finish.
Had these in a flight of Old engine oil, 12,16,30,40. The aroma is slightly peaty, sweet molasses and roast. Similarly sweet palate, watery mid-palate and a sweet and molasses like finish.

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, very very dark brown colour, aroma of dark bread, some peatiness, treacle and a hint of smoke, cakey malty flavour with some charred notes, with touches of alcohol coming through. Quite nice.
12oz bottle pours a dark black with a tan head. Smokey oak aroma. Whiskey smoked malts and chocolate taste.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks zvikar. Bottle #60303. Bottled July 2011. Very dark brown to black with a bit of tan foam. Aroma of chocolate, some roastiness, a bit of whiskey and woody notes. Roasty flavor, slightly smoky, with a chocolate, a bit of whiskey and a drier and slightly alcoholic finish. Medium to full-bodied. Quite nice.

Bottle @ Michael, brew day. Dark brown, small off white head, nice coating. Aroma, malty, roasted notes, dark chocolate, whiskey notes, some alcohol, brown sugar. Taste, roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate, brown sugar, whiskey, coffee notes. Whiskey and chocolate in the aftertaste. Slightly bitter. Little carbonation.

Pours the blackest of blacks. Damn this stuff is black. Staring into it fills me with dread. Its like drinking the night sky. Smells like oak and burnt sugar. Tastes surprisingly salty and very smokey, basically like barbecue sauce, but with a hint of chocolate. The palate is SO smooth and the finish warming, much like the finish on a good whisky. Another reviewer hit the nail on the head when they said its like a dessert. Pretty delicious.

bottle. 
very dark beer, almost no foam, very few and thin bubbles. 
very nice flavour of sugar, caramel, soja, and wood. 
very salty. 
in spite of all the rich flawors, there is still a feeling of lightness.

Definite aroma of whiskey and oak. Very thin head that quickly dies. Taste is very well balanced and surprisingly mellow, whisky is very clear but not at all powerful. This drink is far too easy to drink for an 8%, almost no alcohol at all. Very nice silky smooth. Perfectly executed.
Kolsvart med litet ljusbrunt skum! Doftar mycket whisky och lite rök! Smaken är whisky, choklad, lite lakrits och rökig! Lite blaskig endå! Mycket bra öl! Bottle date Feb 2012

Brune-noire à leffervescence assez marquée, notes en nez de caramel, de cassonade et dalcool fort. En bouche, fruits confits, fruits foncés, le whisky est présent mais discret. Savoureux mais finalement plutôt mince, ce nest pas à son désavantage, elle équilibre ses saveurs avec brio, et lalcool est bien caché ; un peu de boisé en finale. Le genre de bière qui se déguste avec révérence.

Aroma: The smell has burnt wood, earthy and smoky aromas. Some sweetness and licorice.Appearance: The beer is very dark brown, call it black, the small head is beige, leaves some lacing and good curtains.Taste: The taste has much sweet smoke, kind of barbecue sauce character, chocolate with smoked almonds on toast, slightly vinous. Some yeast tones.Palate: Low carbonation, very soft and oily.Overall: A good after-dinner beer, a dessert in itself.Note: Bottle 49161 from July 2009 Reviewed 2011-01-03.

Muyyyy buena!!! Del barril de los 12 años ni noticias, pero todo el resto es nota 10. Super redonda, buen cuerpo, poco carbonatada, bien aromática, cremosa, cafeteada, chocolatada, fumée. Especial, espectacular.

Couleur noire, mousse beige. Nez caramel grillé, malt grillé et note de whisky. Bon corps malgré très peu de carbonation. Gout malt grillé au note de chocolat caramel, limite un peu fumée et note de whisky doux. Longue fin de bouche, petite ametrume. Pas mal! Bien que ce ne soit pas mon style de prédilection.

ps: comme dit cargo150, dans commentaire juste avant, c une bière a déguster lentement.

De couleur noir intense avec un col beige résistant. Nez de fumée de bois et de grains grillés. En bouche la fumée attaque doucement sans être désagréable, avec un peu de chocolat, du bois et des grains grillés. Bien balancé, agréable a boire mais a boire lentement, une bière a dégusté. Une bière a se rapeller excellente et unique en son genre, jaimerai réussir a trouver les autres de cette catégorie!

Bottle. #37106. FEB 2012. Pours jet black with the merest whisper of a thin dark brown head. Nose is whisky, with peaty malts, vanilla, woodchips, nuts, coffee. Tasting it, its earthy - peat, malts, icecream, whisky. Quite thick and slick in the mouth. Lovely scotch alcohol flavours without any bun - and well mixed. You can tell that this has been resting in the barrels "properly". Ive tasted different, which isnt quite as smooth as this. No alcohol burn! Actually surprisingly incredible! Pure class, with a long lingering whisky taste on the palate. Not just a gimmick - I want more!
330ml bottle form Provenance, Edinburgh. Pours near black with little tan head. Slightly smokey aroma, some chocolate malt and maybe soy. More chocolate on the taste, light whisky. good.
(Backlog) Bottle. Slight smokiness in the aroma with oak as well and prunes, dark fruit, and maltiness. Nice smell. Smoke flavors. Thicker body. Roastiness and dryness.
Décevante : manque de caractère et finalement assez courte en bouche, je mattendais à plus de goût provenant du fut de whisky
Sniffs of smoky woods, brined black olives, burnt coffee. Taste is sweet malts, vanilla bourbon, bubbling black gold. Beautiful stuff.

Christmas day Ola Dubh tasting number 1. Bottle no.00494 bottled on Feb 2012. Black beer with small Mocha head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and roasted malts. Taste is wood, licorice, roasted malts, chocolate, dark berries and a hint of whisky. Medium bodied and oily. Very nice.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle, at home. Bottled July 2011. Beautiful bottle. Pours a very black brew. No head to speak of. Aroma of sweet prunes, coffee, and dark malts. Complex flavor - "dark" fruits, licorice, coffee, wood, smoke, peat, caramel, roasted nuts. Medium and smooth body with soft carbonation. Looong lingering aftertaste going through a multitude of the above described flavors. Taste is a bit sweet and a bit acidic. Beautiful.

How: Bottle.
Where: Systembolaget.
Appearance: Black colour with a very small brown head.
Aroma: Malt, chocolate, vanilla, whiskey.
Body: Medium body, low carbonation.
Flavour: Roasted malt, alcohol, caramel, vanilla.

Pours a deep viscous black umber color with a half finger of khaki foam. The nose has a lot of barrel character, char wood, peat, chocolate malts, toffee. Mouthfeel is silky and smooth. Lots of roast, leather, butter, peat smoke and whisky on the palate. Pretty fresh booze profile. Tasty though !

Pours black. The red barely shines through. The cream-coffee colored head begins to dissipate fast, but stays after the initial decay. The earthy nose includes notes of blackcurrant, prunes, tobacco, rye, and woody mushroom. This beer is intense on the palate; savory from front to finish, pointing towards the direction of Worcester sauce, very roasty, dried porcino, dark chocolate, and definitely a caramellic-creamy - but not quite vanilla-ish - component. The medium-bitter finish declines slowly but steadily and is not as brash as you could reasonably expect. The body is almost as full as beer gets; the medium carbonation doesnt stand in the flavors way and pleases the palate as an equal alongside the flavors. A highly complex beer, not recommended for casual consumption.

Pours a viscous black with a tan head. Light carbonation. Chocolate and whisky aroma. Deep, full bodied strong ale with a very palatable flavour. More difficult to discern the subtleties of the flavour compared to Old Engine Oil, as the whisky notes tend to mask them. Lovely sweet chocolate flavour dominates balanced by whisky and oak, hopping is only slightly noticeable on this beer. Excellent.

Dark brown with ruby highlights, tan head. Aroma of bready malts, cocoa, caraway seeds, and a heavy bacon-like smokiness. Flavor is similar, malty with a bready and dry cocoa quality, slightly earthy, nutty notes, more bacon-like smoke, wood, some leather. Medium bodied and slightly warming. Interesting beer but smoke is a little heavy and pushes some of the other elements into the background.
Birra stupenda. Liquorosa, torbata e complessa. Una birra da meditazione per serate imbevute di poesia. Il suo problema è che scende che è un piacere. Quando la si prova poi la si cerca!
33 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma and flavour are roasted malt, whiskey, vanilla, dried fruit, and liquorice  with a dry finish.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2014 (bottled) I would expect more complexity from a 12 year old beer - its nice but simple for something thats been sitting on its ass a decade .

Harviestoun Ola Dubh 12

Almost black pour with just a light tan lacing. Very rich nose. Thick and velvety. Roasted malts and a touch of liquorice. Really thick almost stripy mouth. Boozy. Lots of caramel an malt. Very lie carbonation. Dont need more than one of these.

Bottle from Ber Ritz, Leeds. Pitch black with no head. Sweet smoky oak aroma. Great coffee and chocolate flavours with smoke and oak. Nice balance between bitter and sweet. Whiskey flavour gives it some caramel smoothness on the finish, but slightly overpowers the beer flavours for me.

Draft at Hopcat - complex aromas of scotch and dark fruits . Smooth round mouthfeel . Faint raisin and chocolate flavors . Really interesting beer. Very tasty . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botella de 33 cl ¡Excepcional! De color marrón oscuro casi negro y una espuma cremosa y persistente.Cuerpo medio.El aroma te impresiona ya que te recuerda a maltas tostadas y a la suave leñosidad de la barrica de whisky.En boca su sabor tiene unas ligeras notas de alcohol y recuerda a la madera , el whisky , la turba , humo y maltas muy tostadas , dejando un agradable final tostado. Una cerveza para beber placidamente, pero no para todos los públicos

Bottled Feb 2012, poured into snifter. Black with a small, thin white head. Smell - initial impression is very peaty, a little marmite. Body is medium, a little carbonation and slightly foamy. Up front, the taste is a mixture of smokey peat, chocolate, caramel and marmite. The whisky is subtle and gives sweet vanilla overtones. The more I drink the more dark chocolate I get. Drinkability is high. Im quite impressed.

Black, bitty tan head, clinging mainly to the sides; aroma of milk chocolate, raisins; taste is of smooth milk chocolate, vanilla then sea-spray saltiness from the whisky; smooth, creamy and with no whisky burn at all; excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours an incredibly dark, opaque, black with a creamy cinnamon head with some lace. Nose is vanilla, baking chocolate, molasses, and faint traces of whisky and peat. Dark and smoky like a porter on the front of the mouth, coffee and chocolate predominant, but shifting to a vegetal and herbal whisky nature in mid-palate. Finishes with peat, salinity, and more smoke and coffee. Really intriguing; its definitely a successful merging of whiskey and porter, and manages not to come off too boozy or unbalanced, unlike others Ive had in the past (Brewdogs series comes to mind). Quite good.
Bottle. Pours black with mocha tan head. Nose and taste of vanilla, whiskey, oak, dark fruit, charred wood, toffee malt and toasted caramel. Medium body.
Release 2012 - Bottle 10260. Beer pours with little head...dark chocolate colour. Taste - Chocolate coffee with a slight smokey bitter after taste. A very good beer with lingering flavour

Bottle, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: black beer, small unstable beige head.
NOSE: wood, alcohol, coffee, chocolate.
TASTE: little sour, wood, coffee, little sweet, smoked somewhat.

Was looking forward to this one, first taste wasnt what i expected but realised you need to let it settle after pouring, its nice very dark up to the light you can see a tinge of red, smells like its been squeezed right out of a peat bog. i couldnt place what it tastes like then it came to me! twiglets dipped in soy sauce! not sure if ill finish it to be honest maybe its just my bottle? (number 64879)
Pours black with a very thin tan head. Pete and soy dominate the aroma. Taste has notes of brown sugar, scotch, and cinnamon. Finish is chocolate and scotch

Bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted aroma of dark fruits, chocolate, roasted malt, dark fudge, licorice, whisky, oak, peat and caramel. Taste moderate sweet and bitter and light salty. Body is full, texture is thick and oily, carbonation is soft. Finishes with oak. Definitely less smooth and more distinct barrel-impression than the 18 Y.O.
Rich chocolate, smooth oily palate slightly sticky, hints of wood and smoke. Great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2015 Nera, impenetrabile ed oleosa con un velo appena accennato di schiuma marroncina. Aggredisce il naso con caffè, cacao amaro e forti sentori legnosi e dolciastri. Al palato è intensa e oleosa ma piuttosto liscia e meno corposa del previsto (merito dei 4 anni in cantina magari?) con note di espresso, cioccolato e whiskey. Corpo medio, effervescenza minima, strutturata e setosa. Particolarissima!

330ml bottle. Pitch black colour with small to average, frothy, half-way lasting, moderately lacing, tan head, a thin layer remains. Dark malty aroma with hints of oak and leather. Taste is dry, minimally tart, dark malty, hints of leather, oak. Well balanced, not overdone, good drinkability.

Im really looking forward to this one. Black, with a medium-brown head, no surprise. The aroma... ah, theres the engine oil. But so much better - with whiskey! The nose is full of roasted malts, soft, woody whiskey, and a touch of peat and/or smoke. Its soft, complex, and very impressive. It may not be for everyone, but theres not enough of that peatiness to turn off those who dont care much for it, or smoke for that matter. Some soy and/or steak sauce comes through a little as well. 

Its slick, and although is fairly light, has enough body to stand up to its chewy palate. The flavor is jam packed with delicious notes of alcohol, wood, whiskey, peat, smoke, and heavily roasted malts, leaving a nice numbness on the tongue. The whiskey coats the throat deliciously, contributing to its unique roasted finish. It has all the great flavors of an awesome smoky Scottish stout.. er, old ale, but mellow and smooth. If this really is an old ale, its the darkest, smokiest, smoothest old ale Ive ever had. Very impressive! This would be great with a steak.

Bottle #19875, bottled in Feb 2012. Pours a really, really dark brown with a thin offwhite head that leaves some lacing. Aroma has a nice smoke component that doesnt overpower the rest: tobacco, syrup and roasted malt. Taste is sweet but well-balanced by roasted malt and scotch impressions. Flavors of a fine scotch and roasted malt that also brings a slight acidity to the mix. Mouthfeel is silky and carbonation light. Really nice!

From a 33cl bottle No.28251 Feb.2012. Pours a dark brown to black body with a beige head that did not stay long, only leaving a ring around. Aroma of torrified malts, coffee and liquor. Flavors of strong torrified malts, liquors coffee, hints of hops. Woody, Dry finish, low carbonation. Nice balance of flavors, rich taste in mouth with long lasting flavors.

Bottled. Pours black in color with a small bubbly off-white head. Light peaty notes, quite strong chocolate 

notes, some wooden barrel notes as well is present in aroma. Feels quite sweet and smoky at the start, which 

isnt entirely a bad way to begin the journey. Quite smooth, but yet at the same quite dry mouthfeel. Smoke, 

peat and chocolate in taste. This seems pretty nice. Roasted coffee later on. A slightly better body and 

this would be int the top league, now it just seems a bit thin and lacking the richness I was looking for.

(bottle) pours black in colour with a small frothy beige head. aroma of toffee, light soy sauce, dark chocolate, peat smoke, cobwebs and balsamico. flavour is heavy soy, caramel and brown sugar, quite leathery, with only a hint of smoke and some burning embers. heavy-bodied with soft carbonation.

330ml bottle. Black in colour, frothy tan head and aroma of roast malt, molasses, dark fruits, peat, hint of smoke. Taste is sweetish roasted malt, chocolate, with earthy peat and alcohol notes. Smooth mouthfeel, medium to full bodied, soft carbonation, warming finish. Very drinkable.
This beer tastes really good! Definitely has some whiskey like notes but without the burn.

dark brown, near black, small light brown head with moderate retention. dark fruit preserves, grape jelly, chocolate, vanilla, smoke, mild wood, cherry, slight metallic tinge. medium sweet, light bitter. full body, creamy feel, soft carb.

BOTTLE.

Head: mocha, small, forthy, poor retention. Colour: pitch black.

Aroma: some whisky at the start - but fades out fast, chocolate, peat, some saltiness/soy sauce.

Taste: roasted, coffee, salty, burnt wood/ashes, wood, bitter.
Svart farve med beige skum. Lukt av røster malt og whiskey. Smak av malt, lakris, karamell sjokolade, karamell, kaffe og whiskey. Vinmonopolet.
God duft av malt og lakris. Dyp sort farge. Lite skum langs kant. God smak av malt og lakris med en anelse wiskey taste.

Bottle poured into snifter. July 2011 bottling. Pours black with khaki bubbles and no head. Aroma is peat, whiskey, caramel. Flavor up front is whiskey, peat, malt, some caramel, and a smooth whiskey finish. Slick mouthfeel. The whiskey profile really comes through in the flavor, which is almost too much peat for my liking, but the palate is still complex and unique. Very decent but not great. I bet the 16 year is better.

330 ml. bottle poured in to a snifter. July 2011 bottling. Black with a small, tan head. Sweet aroma with roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, whisky, oak and hints of peat. Taste is sweet. Medium to full body, creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes sweet and roasted with licorice and a pleasant alcohol burn. Excellent cask matured ale. Rather pricey - however, I want to try the other Ola Dubh versions.

bottle from pivni rozmanitost, nice work mowbeer. black and beige in the usual order; aroma of salted vanilla, instant coffee, burnt butterscotch; flavours of rye, caramel, steady and very drinkable but not overly complex

Black with a small tan head. Aroma of whiskey, wood, caramel, chocolate, and roast. Tastes of smoky peat, roasted malts, whiskey and wood. Surprisingly, not counting the whiskey taste, the alcohol is very well hidden here. Medium bodied and slightly oily with light carbonation. Good stuff.
Scotland: Purchased in the grass market. Interesting flavour. Not worth the £.

Bottle from choice beverages McKinney. Pours black with a medium tan head that dissipates quickly. The aromas are coffee, chocolate, soy. The mouthfeel it?s dry, bitter and roasty with a heavy body and low carbonation. Great beer! Cheers!
Bottle. Black oil indeed, low head. Wood and whiskey - peat, flowers, tar salt, roast, dark choc, cigar tobacco. Full, well rounded bode, really well balanced.
Pitch Black color. Chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits, alcohol, coffee.

Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Smells strongly of chocolate and hints of nuttiness. Taste is roasted and smoky. Medium-to-full bodied with a slick texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Harviestoun Ola Dubh 12 Year finishes with a semisweet chocolate kick.

Tried a Feb 2012 dated bottle in July 2013 during a group tasting. Appearance is solid black, very little carbonation. Aroma is burnt and molasses, really good. Also loads of peat, getting the whiskey in there. Taste is bitter, but also some unexpected sweetness throughout. Good follow through, full and tasty all the way through.

Bottle at Brew Wharf. Jet black with a very small sort lived dark tan head. Really viscous. The aroma is oak, choc, soft roast and salt. The flavour is heavy oak and vanilla, some booze. Mellow roast and some berry fruits.

Nice full bodied beer.

Bottle @ home, picked up at 287 Liquor Fort Collins. Pours an oil black appearance with a dark brown head. Roasted, burnt waffles, campfire smoky, char, slight burnt sugar, peaty aroma. Burnt/caramelized caramel/sugar, roasty, earthy, herbal smoky peaty, mild chocolate, lightly boozy flavor. A whole hell of a lot of peat, different than most beers Ive tried in my time, and fairly enjoyable.

Almost opaque dark cola pour with some rusty red hues. Small bead tan head. Nose of chocolate, coffee, toasted wood, and booze. Lots of chocolate on the palate. Oily and whisky background characters. Light smoke and nutty finish. Very much more stoutlike than an old ale. A-4.5, A-4.5, F-8.5, P-4, O-17
2011 bottle..pout is dark black with a thin tan head..Nose is chocolate,roast,tobacco,molasses,smoke...Taste is roasty burnt chocolate,caramel,smoke, dry peat, Palate is dry.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2016 Rerate - first tasting notes were on a bottle that was clearly sub-standard, wont bother to post them - There are so many things about this beer that make me happy. Firstly, a traditional scots beer from a real scots brewery aged in a kickass distillerys whisky casks. Secondly, the flavour is just so intricate and awesome. Bottle 341ml. 8%. Rich dark brown-black pour with a weak white head that bubbles away quickly, no lacing. Aroma is earthy - presence of toasted barley, chocolate, coffee grounds, mild peaty smokiness.Mouthfeel is clean, low carbonation, medium alcohol warmth. Taste is a depth of chocolately, nutty roast malts, tinge of peat smoke, and tremendous character from the wood of the whisky casks - vanilla, oaky. A tremendous brew worthy of high praise.

Bottle: The aroma consists of chocolate, molasses, smoke, whiskey, and just a hint of coffee. It pours a dark brown with very faint orange highlights. It has a small beige head that quickly fades to a minimal film outlined by a thin ring. There is some very thin webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with a quick dose of chocolate and molasses. The finish has notes of brown sugar, smoke, whiskey, and a touch of roasted coffee. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation and a slightly slick mouthfeel. Overall, it tastes like a barrel-aged smoked Imperial Stout.
Wow was a great beer. A very strong taste to it, and long lasting taste, but well balanced that makes you keeping wanting more until next thing you know the bottle is empty.

Bottle. Deep dark brown body with a medium head. Aroma has smokey peat and rich dark malts. Creamy and velvety mouthfeel with lots of flavours. Mostly peat and charry wood. Dry finish. Very good. Right now I prefer this to the 16 and 18 Year Old versions but Im only comparing it to my notes and memories. I should probably do a vertical tasting and rate them all side by side.

Black body, small light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with honey, dark chocolate, coffee, licorice, whiskey, liqueur, wet wood, some floral and smokey notes. Medium body with average carbonation. Excellent complex flavour with smoke, honey, peat, dark chocolate, hints of licorice and wood, with a balanced yet quite peculiar sweet floral finish with vanilla. Excellent.
Très mince en bouche, moka, mélasse, coco dans une soupe étonnamment aqueuse. Un peu déçu.

Bottle 59029 (2011) pours nearly opaque black with thin oily tan head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, nuts, caramel, vanilla, whisky. Moderately bitter and sweet.  Body is mostly smooth with a bit of acidic crispness. Aromas blend well, possibly because of the aging. Nice.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C. Served alongside the Ola Dubh 21, also on draft.

The beer is black with a small tan head. The aroma offers roast, chocolate, alcohol, oak, smoke, scotch. Very nice. Lovely flavor following the scent. Easy to sip and savor. Medium bodied. Vanilla, chocolate, light booze. The 12 year was a bit smoother than the 21 year, actually, though the barrel character was less pronounced. All in all, a delicious beer.

330ml bottle, bottled in February 2012.
Pours a really dark brown, with a brown head.
Complex, roasted, smoky aroma, chocolate, vanilla, wood, coffee, caramel, ashes, fudge, peat, earth, wax, prunes.
Semi-sweet, full bodied, mid to high bitterness, creamy CO2.
Complex, quite smoky taste, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice, ashes, peat, iodine, oak, vanilla, whisky notes, heather, honey.
Very complex, well balanced, lingering finish. (2013-06-08)

Black color with reddish highlights; small head which diminishes quickly into a broken film. Aroma remembers of licorice, coffee, prum, wood and smoke. Mouthfeel is oily, very mellow, body is moderate to strong. Alcohol is perfectly masked. Finish is more sweeter than bitter. Taste is intense dark fruit, licorice, vanilla, chocolate and smoke. Very complex and deep and perfectly balanced.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2013 Pours black, with a (very) thin, milk-chocolatey beige head. Amazing aroma of peaty whisky, chocolate, (light) coffee and smoky, roasted malt, also - this will sound weird (maybe its the smokiness) but it almost smells meaty (like smoked ham or something). Taste is sweet with a light bitter and caramel finish. Thick, smooth texture with very light carbonation. Very good, but a strange taste, which I cant place, but feels like its at the back of the roof of the mouth, which lasts and I cant decide if I like or not.
Bottle. Black beer with a beige medium head. Vanilla, dark dried fruits and chocolate aroma. Similar flavour with smokey notes. Nice one :-)
Smells  of maple and Whisky. Tastes the same with chocolate and smooth scotch whiskey in the aftertaste. Light mouthfeel and short legs.

On draft. Pours a dense black with a beige head of foam aroma has some smoke, wood, dark fruits. Taste is roasty, smoky, woody, dark fruits. Solid beer, maybe not one Id necessarily I would need to drink again, but pretty good.

12oz bottle.  Good looking pour, "black oil" with a tan head.  The taste was definitely different and distinctive thanks to the barrel aging, which has given it a smoky flavor more than anything else.  Im not a "smoke" beer connoisseur or anything, but I liked how it wasnt too overpowering and left the door open for other taste notes, like chocolate to seep in.  Nice beer overall.

Black color with no head. Aroma of dark fruits, molasses, coffee, caramel, smoke, chocolate, cookies. Taste is light to medium sweet with dark fruit flavor and smoke. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Nice old ale

330 mL bottle. Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aromas of salty peat, oak, wood smoke, black cherry, fig and Dr. Pepper. Moderately sweet and richly bodied; lightly carbonated with a slick, saline mouth feel.  Very complex, but well rounded.  A must try for fans of whisky, wee heavies or old ales.
On draft a Pizzeria Paradiso in Old Town, Alexandria, VA.  Pours black with a tan head.  Flavors of caramel with intense smoky whisky notes.

Bottle at home, 24/04/13, from BOE. #02028 Feb 12.
Pours an extremely dark shade of mahogony brown, approaching light black with a good sized tan head.
Nose is rich dark caramel fudge, treacle toffee, dark malts, woody tones, trace of Scotch, brown sugar.
Taste comprises light smoke, treacle toffee, fruit cake mix, demerara sugar, 
Medium bodied with bite, fine carbonation pitched perfectly to leave a smooth massging feeling on the throat.
Overall a great BA old ale, everything is kept in check and nothing overpowers.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
330 ml bottle (#47101).
Color is deep mahogany - almost black - with a thick mocha colored head.
Nose has smoke, chocolate, vanilla and dark fruit.
Very softly carbonated, medium oily body, a little watery and with a short lived bitter aftertaste.
Wooden sweet flavor with chocolate, vanilla, peat, smoke. Whiskey notes are present but not predominant. Very nice old ale.
330 ml bottle. Very dark brown with little head. Aroma smooth and sweet with lots of chocolate and smoke. Taste: chocolate, ash, whisky, wood. Finish is sweet and peaty. Very pleasant beer

330 ml bottle.  Oily dark brown pour with little to no carbonation.  Aroma of oak, roasted malt and molasses.  Thick mouthfeel with a great lacing, this is a beer you can almost chew.  Lasting alcohol finish.

330 ml bottle sampled in 2010. Dark brown, almost black with a small, dense beige head. Aroma has whisky, oak, peat and roast. Flavor is sweet roasted malt, peat, whisky, oak and pleasant bitterness. Fine body and a long aftertaste. A really fine and pleasent, not too intense whisky oaked  beer.

Bottle at the John=Jim Den Haag tasting, Den Haag. Poured a deep, very dark mahogany with a thin tan head. The aroma is rich and peaty. The flavour is huge bitter, lots of liqourice and dark chocolate. The bitterness is alcoholic, but well controlled. A superb beer.

33cl bottle shared.
thin tan head.  Clear black pour.  Lovely smooth taste.  A great beer!

Black with brown head - some roasted malt in the aroma - roasted malt flavours along with some bitterness from the roasted malt - lingering roasted malt finsih with some bitterness - this was quite good

Flaske nr. 50088 (bottled 07/09, bb 07/12): velsmagende og højt skum i mitt Chouffe-glass. Sollyset slipper knapt igjennom det som befinner seg under skumlinjen. Fatlagring ruler! Dette er snadder, forutsatt at man liker skotsk whisky av edlere merker. Franskbrent espresso +  høyoktan sjokolade med litt vanlije og madeira fra fatlagringen. Investeringsobjekt ved neste anledning. Tror jeg avslutter kvelden med a wee dram. Bra jeg alltid har en Highland Park på lur, pt. 1998-årgangen!
Aroma of whisky and chocolate. Taste of whisky, roast, chocolate and coffe. Very good balance.
Dark brown with a red tint. Very small brown head. Sweet malty aroma, whisky, peat, ash. Taste ist malty, nice peat and whisky. More bitter, than I expected. Lovely.

Lots of chocolate and coffee, as well as a mild liquory, whiskey smell. Tastes wonderful, very smooth at first with the chocolate up front, finishing with a warm, slightly sweet/sour whiskey taste. Lives up to the reputation.

330ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a small beige head, which lasts fairly well without leaving much lace. The aroma offers milk chocolate, woody and smoky Scotch whisky and a whiff of Vegemite. Mild herbal hops up front blend with oaky Scotch whisky. Strong milk chocolate comes through in the mid-palate, along with some subtle peppery, smoky Scotch whisky, which builds up into the finish and leaves behind a smoky aftertaste. This is very nice; perhaps not quite up to the standard of Ola Dubh 18, but still a very well-integrated whisky cask ale.

330mL pours a clear, deep brown to black. Larger, dense, coffee foam. Excellent webby lacing. Nose is detergent, soy, salt, tar, baked apple, apple skin. Taste is still a bit thin, ashy, apple skin, mild tar. Just not sure how this series scores so highly. Must have been reviewed a lot in the early days of ratebeer. Nowadays this palate doesnt cut it.

Pours dark brown with a generous light brown/tan head that dissipates quickly. Smells smoky, with notes of dried fruit and prunes. Tastes of chocolate, smoke, roasted malts, and a bitter back end make this a delicious beer. Alcohol is very well incorporated. The best whiskey cask beers I have had.

What a great beer to have on my birthday! Really, really enjoyed this one, and kind of wished (though it was probably for the best) that I sprung the 20 bucks for the 40 year old that was still at the LCBO. What I love about this is how well mixed and balanced the scotch tastes are with the old ale tastes. You still get the malt, mixed with some spices and fruits floating just beneath the surface, but the peat smoke and the scotch flavours come in to make this beer something special. Pours blacker than black, probably the darkest beer I have had (take that Russian Imperial Stouts!) but tastes so smooth. The palate is a bit thin, I agree, but overall its a minor quibble for a beer that is easily in my top 10 if not top 5 beers.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 August 2010 bottle. Pours brown black with very little head. Smooth whiskey and grainy aroma with some grape like sweetness. The taste is smooth stout with a rosy wine like fruitiness and a touch of whiskey. The peat smoke comes out quickly but in a very nice smooth proportion. Very nice, pretty clean flavors, good beer overall.

aroma: toast, chocolate, coffee, woody, smoke, peat (torba)
apparenza: black, sparkling, minimal head, white foam, 
gusto: lightly bitter, medium sweetness, 
palato: full body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish, 
birra imbottigliata a febbraio 2011,bevuta a febbraio 2013..bottiglia spettacolare,firmata,con etichetta,tracciabilità della botte,insomma uno spettacolo..idea veramente meravigliosa quella di invecchiare questa birra in botti di whisky..sarà il mio amore per laffinamento in botte e soprattutto per il whisky scozzese,ma questa birra è per me un capolavoro..aroma affumicato e torbato,lievissimi sentori di luppolo e di malto..birra scura come la notte,schiuma che si dissolve rapidamente..in bocca è moderatamente frizzante,oleosa (come la birra che mettono ad invecchiare,la old engine oil)..il gusto è complesso e sicuramente prevalgono sapori forti,caffè,malto tostato e affumicato e la torba,meravigliosa che ricorda il whisky ma che ovviamente non è così prepotente come nel whisky..finale lungo e piacevole,riscaldante..bevuta al santo bevitore

11.2oz bottle. Bottle No. 08978, bottled Feb 2012. Dark brown / black but still clear color. Pretty much black. Nice one-finger thick bubbly creamy light brown head, good retention and lace. Looks good. Kind of an interesting, savory nose... Beef jerky? Roasty malts. Whiskey not as strong as I expected in this, but its noticeable. Call it balanced, in the nose. Barrel and wood are noticeable in the flavor. Much less sweet vanilla notes that Im used to from American whiskey barrel-aged brews. Bigger body. Light, crisp carbonation. Nice light chewiness to the aroma, good body. Good dark chocolate note. Light roasty coffee. Very good!

Nice dark ale with a wee dram in the bottle. Oily indeed, thick dark brown, almost black, with a respectable brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and peaty smoke  yes, I was not even sure if the single malts of Orkney were peaty, but I did get a strong peaty vein in that nose. Nice. But as the beer warms up the aroma turns pungent, stinging, almost repugnant, somewhat resembling what one would whiff at a Ukrainian roadside toilet. The flavours are comfy, chocolate, roasts, the peat, that wee dram of single malt. Woody, strong, but comfy. It is a mouthful of warmth, and the finish is quiet, until it irradiates that wooden warmth in all directions from the tongue. Not bad indeed, but I dont know if I would have it over a choice of a nice dark ale or a peaty single malt.
Pours a dark oily black nice retained brown foam. Hints of whiskey.  Very well balanced  slight hoppiness. Could have been a little more full bodied but still a very good beer.
330ml bottle courtesy of JohnRMurdoch - very dark brown near black, no head, fruity, whisky, alcohol aroma, sweet roasted malt flavour, hint of vanilla, bit smoky, rather nice
330ml bottle from Sainsburys. almost black colour, not much head. Roasted fruit aroma. Toasted Whisky malt flavour. Smooth with burnt aftertaste. Not really my type of beer but not bad.
Chocolate and leathery aroma and taste. Slight aftertaste of whiskey. Clearly less pronounced than in the 40years version.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with no head whatsoever. Aroma is full of dark malts, with strong roast and some bitter dark chocolate. Flavor starts with strong roast and a bit of coffee with bitter chocolate and dark grains.

Bottled July 2011.  Pours thick with the appearance of motor oil.  No head.  Aromas are smoky, peaty, and unmistakably of wood.  Intially smooth taste but bitter on the finish.  Pleasant, but slightly overrated.  Spend a few dollars more and buy the 16-year.
330ml bottle. Pitch black color, tiny brown head. Licorice, plums, roast, sweet aroma. Roast, malty, dark fruits, grainy notes in flavor. Bit thin, but still wonderful beer.

0.33 L bottle from Vinmonopolet Nettbutikk. Body is dark brown to black with deep mahogny edges. Medium tan head. Rich, well roasted chocolatey malt aroma. Subtle whiskey tones, and a hint of raisins and ash. Taste is well roasted dark malts, yet smooth and chocolatey. Notes of whiskey liqueur and dark dried fruits. Slick juicy texture. Feels full in the mouth. Tarry and ashy endnotes. Nice all over.

This beer has motor black oil colour. Its head is tasty, but very small and dissapears quickly. Roasted aroma with coffee, whisky, and smoke. The flavour mirrors the aroma but with more roasted malt, and it actually feels lighter than expected from the aroma. Slick mouthfeel, and a light to medium bitterness. A very nice and rich ale, but light at the same time. Balanced and with a lasting flavour, and proper amout of sweetness at the end.

Bottle at home. Has a black colour with a small grey-beige head. Roasted aroma with coffee, whisky, smoke, oak and ash. The flavour mirrors the aroma but with more roasted malt, and it actually feels lighter than expected from the aroma. Slick mouthfeel, and a light to medium bitterness. A very nice and rich ale, but light at the same time. Balanced and with a lasting flavour, and proper whisky touch in the end.
Bottle at home on a snowy evening, 19th January 2013, this is lovely, slick and full o flavour, rich and warming, a perfect winter warmer

Murky brown/black. Tan head faded immediately. Aroma of burnt dark sugar and smoke. Flavors of roasted dark grains - espresso, burnt and smokey. Finish is dry and a touch harsh. Unique but very over-priced.
~stout. Épais, velouté. Chocolat, légèrement fumé, whisky peu présent. Très agréable à boire mais manque de caractère par rapport à Old Engine Oil

Aroma: Coffee, Chocolate, smoke

Appearance: Poured dark, caramel head

Taste: hit of coffee followed by a smoky barrel flavor. The barrel lingers

Overall: Average beer, nothing special, especially for the price.
Dark black, like oil.  No head.  Smells like burnt wood.  Initially tastes like ashes, but there is no finishing flavor.  Its a decent experience, but I wouldnt buy again.
Botella 33 Cl. Rica combinacion de oscura cerveza con buen whiskey.

Aroma of moderate peat, bitter chocolate, oak, raisin and port. Appearance is opaque black with sticky mocha head. Flavor is an amalgamation of chocolate, raisin, roast and wood, finishing with more peat and wood. This beer is full bodied, lively (hot) and slick. An intense drinking experience; Im glad I shared my bottle with a friend.
Bottle from lcbo a: chocolate, dark caramel, cherry. App: pitch black no head. T/p: full body with sweet medium long finish. Soft carbonation. O: great excellent balance and classy.

Pours jet black, tan head which soon settles. Scotch whiskey, oak, oats, roast malt. Absolutely incredible aroma. Heavy roast malt dominates the flavour, thankfully the whiskey is not overdone. The slightest nuance of peat intertwines with the bitter hop character. Slick, robust, warming with a finish which goes on forever. This beer is a work of art.

Svart med litet brun-grått skum. Doft: Tjära, trä, bränt socker, vanilj, romrussin, choklad, chili, lakrits, kola. Smak: Kaffe, lakrits, tjära, rök, trä, cola, bränt socker, mineraler, söt jäst smak och lite hav.

Bottle @ our annual Christmas night bottle share...  Fragrant, herbal wood and peat on the nose. Some sweetness and dark fruits up front with a peated malt and bittering character coming through in the finish.  Ashy, chalky, and lots of wood here. A nice sipper.

Small bottle (33 cl). Thick, black and viscous, with a small tan head. Very rich on the nose and tongue. Reminds me of a good, rich imperial stout, but with a little added complexity. Id have to attribute that to the fact that its aged in old whiskey barrels. Thatd do it! Phenomenal!

Thick easy dark tan head. Rich deep aromas of well baked dark chocolate cake and coffee. Thick blanket body is firm and smooth in the mouth but seemingly light. A velevety dark chocolate and earthiness to taste. MAsculine and balanced. Top notch.

Bottle.  Black pour, thin tan head.  Great aromas of dark chocolate, wood, hints of roasted coffee and toffee.  Thick.  A bit sticky. Not too rich.  Cocoa and a little coffee. Earthy/peaty with a touch of pine hoppiness on the finish. A litte light on the scotch but it was there.  Guess I have to try the 16!  Balanced and flavourful.  Delicious.

Tasted from the bottle, in August 2012.
Aroma isnt very intense, with notes of wood, whiskey spirits, caramel, toffee.
Taste is just ok, medium body.
Aftertaste is better, but still has too strong wood character.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pitch black beer with a nice rich brownish head. Roasted aroma, peat, smoke, oily, malty, prunes, figs, licorice, salty, some cocoa. Malty chocolate flavor, caramel, alcohol, smoke, peat, salty, spices, figs, licorice. Nice body and with a salty oily finish bringing figs, licorice, caramel and smoked notes.
Bottled. Pours black with a small brown head. Smells abit smoky, roasted, whiskey. Tastes abit smoky, roasted malt, whiskey, abit spicy with a similar finish.

Bottle to Snifter, super-tan quarter inch head with nice micro-bubbles dancing underneath it, dissappears quickly leaving an oily little slick of bubbles on the surface. This beer is as black as they come and for some reason appears sharp + glassy to my eye. Huge tabacco and peat aromas wafting off this, Im assuming the highland park barrels have something to do with this. First sip reveals super complex flavors, smooth roasted chocolate on the front end transitioning to peaty scotch notes finishing in (dont take this the wrong way) cigarettes on the back end. There is so much going on here each sip reveals new experiences. Good lacing as it goes down, this beer is somewhere different in the whole barrel-age the fuck out of everything thing thats going on these days and I like it and will seek it out. Finish lingers on the palate for a while in the top of your mouth with some vinegar notes that are not bad in any way.
Pours black.  Smoky and toasted malts aroma, smoky and salty taste. A little alcoholish, I really enjoyed this beer.

Pours a solid black with a tan foamy head and lacing. It has of toasted malt and some caramel, with a bit of the scotch in the background. The flavor has the same description, with the malt flavors up front, followed by a great smoke and peat aftertaste and a syrupy, sticky texture.

Pours black as night with cream head. Surprising amount of carbonation for age. Heavy smoky aroma. Lots of roast and smoky malt. Some bitterness and sweetness. Great beer, cant believe I didnt buy this earlier. Seen it hanging around the licbo for a while. Very musky and pungent. Bottle.

Bottle poured black with limited tan head. Aroma is smoky , toasted malts  ,roasted meat . Taste is sweet caramel with smoky salty meatiness underlying. Finish is a smoky bitterness but lighter than a rauchbeer style. Medium carbonation with thick oily mouthfeel

Bottle at Ipanema Bar, Trilofos: Black colour with small tanned head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. Taste pretty much the same. Bittersweet finish, low carbonation, full body. Overall, loved it.

Tasted @ Grain Cru - Roll Out the Barrels, Belgian Beer Café.Produced up an oily though lean darkest brown with no head and very little life. Mixed-bag, heady aroma of bonfire ash, heather, molasses, vanillin, fatty lipids, wood and damp moss, top soil and peat. Initial sour, salty and umami dredge upon the tongue wanes to reveal powdery, blackened malts, molasses and burnt sugar, dust and smoke. Very woody, raw, dry and warming in the finish with residual smoke and char. The body oily but light on with only a light spritz of upfront carbonation. Aroma doesnt carry onto the palate as well as anticipated. A little thin to be honest but wonderfully aromatic. (33cL, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

Light brown weak head. Black colour. Aroma is malty, roasty with earth, milk chocolate and tobacco notes. Flavor is malty too with fruity (banana), earthy, chocolatey and slightly smoky finish, ending in a chocolatey and gently smokey finish. Full bodied.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2013 pours black as soot with very short off-brown head and minimal retention, slight carbonation.  aroma is promising with heavy molasses and smoke masking ever so present hops. Bottle purchased at a Brantford LCBO. Pours midnight black with some tan brown on the edges and head. Head is fairly thin layer tat spikes up to these towers on the glass walls. Nose is sweet malt with caramel and some smoke and oak. Tastes  sweet caramel again, has a smoke flavour (not like a Rauschenberg beer) mainly on the finish, oak is present as well. Complex, but balanced.

Pours oily, with murky thin head. Aroma is of dark fruits, spice and alcohol. Taste matches the aroma. Not much whisky, but its there. Warming.
Very good.

Light, but somewhat sharp carbonation that has a nice blanketing effect, could be a bit softer, but it still suits the beer well as is.

This is actually my first old ale review so take this with a grain of salt... not sure if Im head over heels with this style or I was just lucky to get one of the best... maybe a little bit of both. The oily blackness fits perfectly with the peatiness and small taste of dark dark moka. Ive had beers with a whiskey flavour and found it detracted, as it was too empowering for my tastes (I do like whiskey but prefer not to drink hard alcohols). In this one it really enhanced the flavours.My Dads always hated beer. Ive tried to get him to open up by sharing some "outsider" styles, like imperial stouts and lambics... as hes a whiskey fan, this might be the one to finally pull him over.

had this by chance in a resteraunt on the recommendation of the waiter - very pleased with the results. As a whisky lover I thought it might be an interesting experiment to see a nice ale matured with whisky but it turns out that it makes a brilliant winter warmer.

Pours black with a somewhat thin, oily brown head that has gread retention and leaves some sparse lacing, the beer itself coats the class in a nice way without appearing to oily or thick. Aroma is chocolate, leather tobacco, roast, char, light woody, iodine, light peat, a touch of soy sauce and a decent amount of port soaked dark fruit. Flavor is roast, smoke and chocoalte up front, seems sweeter than I expected, nice tobacco notes, dark fruit, light vinous notes, weathered wood, a little soy sauce (not very strong, and it fits well), saline, earth, toasted wood, light peat and iodine. Bottle. All black, tiny beige head. Low carbonated. Aroma of spices, plums, cake and whisky. taste of malt, chocolate, alcohol, burned wood. Viscious. Bittersweet warming finish, an enjoyable beer!

Black pour, thick dirty brown head that leaves a nice ring. Coffee, caramel, yeast, and the sweetness of the cask. Palate is great. Syrup feel from the barrel is muted, which I like. Doesnt over-power the other flavours. 040312

Great beer, pours a dark brown. cask comes through nice. Would buy again.
Bottle in Dublin. Nice beer but really strong. I recommend but not for the first one.

Extremely drinkable and charismatic old ale.  Aroma is toasted from the oak and the pour is dark.  The mouthfeel is soft yet strangely adherent to your expectations, despite the smoky aroma. Bottle pour. Dark brown. Roasted nuts, toffee, warming scotch, wood, more pronounced fruits than in 18 yr.

Poured into a snifter. Bottle #25,160 from September 2007.

3.0 A: Black color. Maybe a quarter finger of frothy light brown head that quickly fell and left no lacing. Ill cut it some slack since its so old.

5.0 S: This may be the strongest smelling and booziest of the series and also the best smelling. Tangy caramel, loads of chocolate, light coffee, vanilla combine to form a creme brulee type aroma. Molasses, a formitable earthiness, and peat and oak from the whiskey and barrel. Supple roast underneath. I wouldnt ask for a much better nose, but if I did, Id ask for a little more sweetness. 

3.0 T: The frailty of the base beer is quite apparent in the taste. Aside from roastiness and some chocolate, the taste is dominated by the whiskey instead of the whiskey playing complement to the base. Most of the flavors found in the nose are still there, but in vastly reduced amounts with chocolate, molasses, and caramel taking the biggest hits. Still a decent amount of vanilla and oak from the barrel and peat from the whiskey. Earthy mineral from the water.

2.0 M: Light to ligher medium body. Whatever the descriptors, its too thin. A good bit undercarbonated, but not quite flat. Lacking creaminess. 

2.5 D: These beers smell great, but then ultimately disappoint. The base for these is weak and the barrel overshadows it by far too much. Only the 18 year to go, then Im done with this unsatisfying, overpriced series.

Wow... beautiful aromas loaded with stuff. Molasses that are softened by maple syrup, roasted malts and dark fruits all rounded-up by mild chocolate. Right before breathing though, much more was there: burnt wood, nuts and peat. Slightly oily mouthfeel that just sticks a bit. The taste is pretty decent, but lacks the character the nose has. Milder all-around with the dark fruits, chocolate, molasses, roasted malt and some earth in the finish. Seems like the smokiness disappears (so hard to detect the Highland Park barrel). Still, a great brew to enjoy slowly.

July, 2009 bottle drank 3/9/12.  This is what Mikkellers Scotch Black Hole should have been.  The Highland Park is a great choice...a big, peaty smokey Islay malt is way too much.  The Highland Park is far more mellow and blends perfectly with the beer.  Its there, but it doesnt punch you in the face and overwhelm everything else.  Dark, almost no head or lacing.  Scotch, vanilla, and some wood on the nose.  Scotch, dark malt, and a big long dark roast coffee finish.  Very well balanced.  Im gonna go get some more of this for the cellar.
Bottle from Kokkens Vinhus, Glostrup. Black with a tan head. Aroma and flavour of malt, chocolate, dried fruit, alcohol and whisky.

It pours jet-black with a slight brown tint; the head is beige and fluffy. The aroma has notes of: wood smoke, soy sauce, peat, yeast, dark chocolate, and slight coffee. The taste is medium sweet that finishes with a bitter note; there are notes of: dark chocolate, black coffee, soy sauce, and a sour yeasty quality. The palate is medium-light body, aqueous, with a short finish. Overall, my dog it needs a backbone, just too thin and watery.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2013 + zeer lekkere zoete karamel geur.
+ zachte bitter smaak
+ lichten whiskey smaak, met een sla nasmaak
+ Zachte room smaak
- er is helaas niks van de zoete geur terug te proeven.

Dark ale aged in Highland Park casks. Black beer, but not quite "old oil". Quite fizzy, but little head. Roast malt and slight hop aromas. Slight smokiness to the dark roast malt flavours, followed by a hint of sweetness before a hoppy, bitter finish which lingers. Perhaps lacks a little body for a beer of this strength.

Jet black slick pour with a small tan lid. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, raisin, peat, roasted malt and whisky. Bags of flavour come through on the palate. Heat from the whisky, sweet from the chocolate and dark fruit, slightly bitter from the coffee and earthy from the peat and roasted malt. My lips are ever so slightly sticky.

Absolutely delicious!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours clear pitch black with a small brownish head. Nice aroma with a strong whisky smell to it. Lots of caramel and raisins in the nose as well. Has a nice sweetness in the taste with just enough bitter at the end. Nice long lingering finish with some whisky flavour in it. Creamy feeling and low carbonation. Very enjoyable and a good example of combination with whisky barrel.
bottle.  Poured opaque brownish-black white a creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate malt. Full, thick mouthfeel, some alcohol on the tongue. Roasty flavour, notes of smoke, raisins, dark chocolate.

Pensively, philosophically, I give this an appearance of "4".... the head just isnt amazing enough, the body still a murky red-black instead of a distinctive colour. Therefore, almost there, but not quite. The aroma? Wet and burnt barley, a hint of hops, nothing too exciting for this style of beer, but at least it smells. The flavour is much the same, barley and hops thrown together without a thought of how they might dance together; wet finish. A shame, really, - theres no finesse here, no "je ne sais quoi", there is simply a heavy barley malt and some hops boiled together to make a stout-type brew. Sure, it works, its all right, but it doesnt stop your heart - not even with the alcohol content! It is just, ultimately, and sadly,,,, - average.

Binnys LP 330ml ($9): Pours black with a brown head (surprise... not really). Aroma is wonderful. Its like getting all the positive aspects of a Scotch aroma combined with all the positive aspects of a beer aroma. In other words, it is smoky and has a nice roasted malt backbone to bolster it up properly. Upon tasting it, I was expecting something significantly more intense, but I was by no means displeased with the content of my first sip. The Scotch is subdued, rather than overbearing like some barrel-aged beers (perhaps because I have mostly had experience with Bourbon aged). The body is way lighter than I anticipated and again this is a good thing. The bitterness of Old Engine Oil is taken down a notch, but still manifests itself. In short, the balance is excellent. The beer turned out to be a substantially better sipper than I thought, and I have no regrets.

Bottle 330 ml from erzbierschof.ch. Aromas of roasted-torrefied, dry fruits, molasses, burnt toffy. The taste is rich of grilled malt, roasted, caramel-syrup, wood, vanilla, raisins and figs. Well-rounded. The texture is dense, oily, velvety. Notes of Whisky, tar, hop. fruity acidity. Real Ale of comfort formidable.

Poured from bottle No 44174, deep dark brown with an amazing tanish thick pillowy head that lasted with great lacework down the glass. Champange like carbonation showing the finest of bubbles. The aroma produces sweetish caramel notes. The palate is absolutely wonderful, its a very very smooth beer, its creamy with notes of figs, spice, bitter chocolate and slightest hint of smoke. Outstanding!
(bottle) clear dark brown with small white head; aromas of stewed fruit, brown sugar, molasses; sweetish flavour, tasty

My Bottom Line :  
Intertwining smoke, wood, roast, peat and blackberry flavors lead to a lightly charred roastiness in the finish and an elegantly peat-y aftertaste.

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A sheet of foam lays atop the blackness with dark brown edges.
-A light chocolate undertow seeps from the malt mélange. 
-The soft effervescence lets all flavors express themselves at will. But, amazingly, all show restraint. Truly classy from aroma to finish. 
-I found this one softer and easier to sip on than the other versions of Ola Dubh. Just a wonderful lineup overall.

Bottle.

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours deep brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, oak and vanilla. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat.

Aroma: very malty, light soy, smoke, dark berries, candy sweet, rye, roasted,  liqourice, vanilla, Taste: roasted, rye bread, malty, light smoke, fruity, ashy, liqourice, chocolate, a bit thin bodied, some roasted bitterness , light sugar burn.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2012 11.3 oz bottle poued Black witha thin tan head.  Aroma and taste of coffee, chocolate and scotch.  Delicious

bottle #09340 dated July 2009 - Poured side by side with a 40 yr bottle. Its dark brown with a small tan head. The aroma is rich in chocolate with notes of smoke. The whisky aroma is obvious on first opening and then seems to fade. The flavor is of sweet chocolate and smoky whisky with light carbonation, a bit lighter body than I expected, and a smoky finish. Good brew.

Pours black with a large, light tan head.
Nose shows smoky peat, burnt caramel, figs and nuttty notes. The smoky character seems to a have a burnt rubber note to it though.
Lots more smoky peat as part of the flavours however the caramel is more pronounced making for a more balanced mix of characters. Some booze is noticeable in the soft whisky notes alongside cola.
Could do with more carbonation, very low at the moment.
A bit too smoky with not enough malt to balance it out.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a great head. Aroma and taste of chocolate, malts, licorice, coffee and a great highland whisky. From my Backlog.

A nice reddish black hue with a thin and quickly fading tan head.  The lack of carbonation gave it a  nice viscus look.   Aroma had great malt notes, a mix of caramel, roasted and mild chocolate.  There was a nice peat quality to it and some wood.  Flavor was initially sweet from both the caramel and chocolate malts.  The roasted malts seemed to balance out the sweetness and was a great bridge to the flavors from the scotch.  The peat and wood notes were  enough to give the beer the right flavor without taking away from the malty goodness to it.

2007 Vintage.  Pours a black semi watery looking with zero head.  Smell is slightly vegetal, dark aged fruit and some basement musk.  Taste is more vegetal, some booze, muddled fruits, roasted malts.  Feels a bit washed out from its former glory and I think it was a case of bad storage from the former owner.  Still very nice to try after 4 years.

New Year?s Eve tasting Flight (1 of 3 8:20p)) Bottle 06659/Sept 2007 - Pours whisper of tan foam. Black body. Bit of carbonation clinging to glass side. Aroma of lite soy sauce. Flavors of soy, prunes and charred steak. Slight warmth in back of throat. Tar flavor lingers on palate. A bit of chewiness in the mouthfeel. Glad I finally got around to trying this.
