Bottle thanks to my sister. Pours very dark brown with dense rocky light brown coloured head. Complex aromas with dark fruits, mocca, soy sauce, alcohol and roasted grains. Soy tends to come through a bit more as it warms. Flavours are a little more straight forward. Very sweet with bucket loads of dark malt. Alcohol on the finish. Nice beer.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Roast malt and light coffee. Booze. Light whisky. Delicious.

Pours totally black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is roast malt, with coffee, whiskey and wood. Taste is also roast malt, whisky and coffee with notes of alcohol leading to a nice dry and woody finish. Really amazing.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Chocolate, malt ans some roast coffee aroma. More of the same in the taste. Smooth and delicious.
From bottle. Near black with little tan head. Slightly smokey aroma, little malt and soy sauce. Similar tastes, some chocolate going on.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Ha!  Bottle dated September 2007.  Guess I forgot about this one in my basement.  Aged surprisingly well, though the flavor and aroma are probably pretty mellowed at this point.  Aroma of light whiskey, some wood, and a touch of soy sauce.  Flavor is very woody with black malts showing through.  Pretty solid.

(Dégustation offerte par rodenbach99, merci Yan)  Une bière noire avec une petite tête brune.  Un nez très intéressant qui est fait de parfums chocolatés et de caramel brûlé avec une présence intelligente et réussie de notes boisées et de whiskey.  Des saveurs riches, fait de grains légèrement brûlés avec des traces de café et de chocolat, de mélasse avec une touche salée et une acidité qui semble provenir de la barrique et des houblons.  Le Highland Park est goûteux mais jamais agressif : une véritable leçon dintégration.  En bouche, le liquide est expansif avec son corps crémeux et son pétillement modéré.  La finale est superbe, dune belle complexité, pleine de notes rôtis qui se frottent à une très fine acidité et à des notes justement dosées de whiskey.

33cl bottle. Poured a black beer with frothy tan head. Good lacing and moderate lasting. Aroma is to dark coffee, roasty, moderate toasty and vanilla notes. Flavour is toasty, vanilla, moka, dark chocolate, burnt wood and with a final dominating dark coffee notes. Dense on palate. Carbonation is soft. Body is high. Texture is creamy.

330ml bottle, no. 26526, deep black color, with a thick bubbly tan head, earthy, chocolate, roasted, black, wheat malt, chocolate cake nose, with some chocolate pudding, chocolate oat granola bar accents, with a light chocolate coated fruitcake, toffee, light coffee note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a smooth earthy cereal black, chocolate, roasted, toasted, caramel malt, burnt woody oak barrel, chocolate fudge character with some chocolate cake, faint peat malt smokiness, light roasted grounded coffee bean, fruitcake flavours, with a mild cappuccino, dark bitter chocolate undertone, leading towards a warming, velvety, chocolatey, chocolate pudding, black coffee, dark dried  fruitiness, peat roasted malt bitterness finish.

Bouteille de 330ml. Achetée en Ontario (merci Vincent) et partagée avec Patrick. Bière brune très foncée presque noire, la mousse est peu présente. Le nez est de chocolat, de mélasse, de vieux baril de whiskey, le boisé est bien présent et dalcool (elle traverse le tout). La bouche est ronde, boisé (whiskey), des tanins de fûts de chêne sont perceptibles, il y a une touche de poussière (verdure) en fin de bouche. Elle me semble plus mince que la version «naked», soit sans bois.

Very black pour with a thin light brown head.  The aroma has a little bit of saltiness and molasses along with a little bit of caramel, toffee and vanilla/brown sugar.  Intense and chewy with a lovely rich milk chocolate aroma in addition to some light licorice.  A soft smokiness along with a touch of peppery ethanol on the back.  Its much lighter than the other finishes, but that fact lends it a drinkability that I quite enjoy.  A little bit of coffee and some light roastiness.  Lovely really.

330ml brown bottle. Black pour, almost opaque, throws some deep brown highlights when held to the light. Light brown head with a tight bead, fades to a thin but lasting layer on the surface Minimal lacing, but there is some random spotting. Nose is of roast and some chocolate malt, nice highland notes. In the mouth the beer is deeply chocolately, roasty notes, some earth and wood, coffee beans. Dry finish with wood and earth and roast. Whisky notes are present without forceful alcohol. Silky texture, gentle carbonation, very smooth. Excellent beer, cannot wait for the others in this series.

330 ml. bottle, numbered 28579, bottled July 2009. Pours a long duration beige head, with some lacing, over a black (SRM 40) body.....nose is whisky, chocolate, beef, soy, vanilla...taste is light whisky, chocolate, touch of coffee, vanilla, beef, touch of soy, Marmite, hints of dried fruits including raisin, cherry...mouth feel thick, chewy, alcohol hidden. Rich, thick, complex, nourishing, wonderfully balanced, with neither the cask nor the whisky dominating makes this delicious beer a standout. BJCP 8/3/16/4/8.

from bottle, as has been described umpteen times pours a deep black colour with a thin light brown head. deep smokey malt aroma, treacle and roasted chestnuts. Unlike Brewdog Paradox Arran this has benifitted and developed in the cask, lovely rich flavours, deep and complex. Nicely balanced though allowing you pick out the elements mixed in there. Wouldve been nice to have some Highland Park to go along side it as an accompaniment.

Bottle, Rehills, Ncl. Rich and thick, pours fairly flat (this was seved cool from the garage). Impressed by the smoothness, it has the oily charateristics of Highland Park, subtle smokiness, with woody notes and a warming finish. Leather and licquorice flavours compete with dark chocolate, has an alcoholic aroma with whisky fumes coming off nicely. A great winter evening sipping beer.

Nose is very much molasses, very strong, like I am actually smelling molasses, there are some roasted grains evident as well, reminiscent of Highland Park 12-Year Old Single Malt, it gets smokier as it approaches room temperature; pours black tar with a hint of green, totally opaque, thick but no head to speak of and the lacing is translucent but very thick. May have been chilled too long; Taste is very big, very strong slightly sweet, and tart, sour finish, sprightly carbonation but it is fading fast; Palate is heavy, good carbonation, textrue is thick, oily, sticky and creamy - go figure; OVERALL; Overpriced. And, at this price Id rather have the Highland Park. But, it is very good. Next time I will try this room temperature. I hear the head is impressive

Pours pitch black with only the slightest suggestion of a russet note in the dimple of a glass. Caramel coloured head that subsides in short time. The aroma is completely beguiling. Theres caramel, plummy notes, molasses, apricots, leather and redwood sawdust. Theres quite a lot going on, hints of smoke and oaky vanilla. I love the whisky, and that this is cask aged. Highland Park is in my top ten whiskies (because asking me to choose between them is like asking me to choose my favourite niece or nephew).
Big and oily. This first thing that comes to mind as well as the second and third things. Its a little sweet and then theres full on plumminess, fruitcake and molasses. Brandy even? It sits on the palate and stays. It stays and is powerfully flavoursome. This easily slides into my top five beers ever. Stunning.
Bottle. Malt smoke aroma. Black. No head. Whisky whiskey flavours all over. Sweet finish. Pleasant strange brew.
Its hard to enjoy a beer when it costs this much, but Harviestoun is that good.  The aging process gives its malt profile added definition.  Oily black and coffee finish.

Bottle. Pours dark brown-black with a thin blanketing on tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, malt, peat smoke, along with mild notes of scotch. Flavour is sweet and moderately bitter, some wooden flavours. medium bodied. Exceptional.

Mycket drickvärd old ale, doftar av söta, chokladiga toner. Smaken överraskar med sin frånvaro av riktig beska. Lite saltig i smaken som påminner om havssaltet i whiskyn. Dracks på Bishops Arms tillsammans med Emmelie, Jenny, Niklas H och Ida.

11.2oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours very deep brown with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, whiskey, a little oak and dark cereal, and some hops.  Flavor a nice blend of these.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.
Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Sweet and roasty aroma with some nice boozy whiskey-like notes. The flavor has sweet malts, roast, chocolate, leather, and whiskey. Downright delicious.

bottle 00401 (2/10)@home 5/11/11
Dark brown beer with aromas of pineapple,rasins, fruit cake and marzipan. Hint of smoke and a musky rusk finish. Dry chocolate and subtle peat flavours. Gentle carbonation and slightly oily texture.

Bottle (in NZ), shared with yalnikim and much anticipated. A heavy sweetness on the nose had me at awares. But there was no need, as that did not carry through to the palate. Vanilla and milk chocolate were the most lingering attributes that were impressed on me. There were touches of smoke and fruit as well. Definitely a beer to share, and better for it.

Bottle poured a translucent dark reddish brown nearly black with a small lasting creamy brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, peat smoke, bakers cocoa, oak and light iodine. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, peat smoke,oak, bakers cocoa and light iodine with a smooth lingeringpeat smoke finish.
Smelled weak but woodey, bready and tofee.  poured with no head and a nice lasting that stuck around but not on the glass.  tasted wood bread and flat.  decent beer

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Almost a black pour with a thick and foamy beige head. Very good lacing. Nose shows sweet roasted malts, peat and dark chocolate. More peat in the taste with notes of wood, chocolate and whiskey. Good beer and well done but lacks a bit of punch. Looking forward to the 40 year old though

33cl bottle. Pitch black colour with small head. Aroma is alcohol, malts, dark chocolate and some dark caramel. Flavour is bitter with notes of alcohol, oak, dark chocolate, sugar. Some vanilla. Medium long aftertaste.
Smokey and peaty. Much like the 18yr but a little smoother.  Very nice stuff. Serving: Bottle

Bottle from the LCBO. Black with a dark tan velvet head. Smoke/peat, vanilla,  light whiskey, some plum. Nice carbonation, medium bodied, sweet with a mild bitterness that develops more on the finish along with some whiskey notes, fairly smooth. Actually like this better then the 30 and 40 (although those with some more age on them might have been better).

Almost black with a big and dense light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, dried fruit, vanilla and a little whisky. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. Great balance. Im not normally a fan of old ale, but this is excellent. 270911

2007 bottle. Pours black with no head. Aroma of an old world spiced fruitcake. Palate is very interesting and is consistency of a ligh syrup. Taste hints of soysauce. Hints of smoke and a finish and aftertaste of whisky.

Sampled at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2011. September 3, 2011

Flowery aromas of spices, fruit - especially plums and pears, and whisky. Soft and slightly peppery. Complex. Sweet with a flavours of soft whisky and chocolate. A small mustyness in the end.
Smoky aroma of roasted malt and brown sugar. The taste is soft, sweet and slightly smoky with hints of roasted malt and oak notes. After-taste is slightly burnt and dry. Very pleasant to sip on!

Bottle - 330ml. Pours a black opaque body with low carbonation and a lasting beige creamy head. Wonderful malty/hoppy aroma with whisky, oaky and some chocolate hints. Taste is complex and very well balanced. It carries plummy, vineous, oaky, and anise notes. Ends with a long, robust, warming bittersweet finish. Awesome!
Allot of pears, vanilla, young whisky. Light to medium body, quite fun beer to have tried.

330ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
Bottle #: 05015 
Best Before: February 2014 
I  tried this beer on August 16, 2011 after purchasing from one of my local LCBO outlets. The beer poured a very dark brown colour with a long lasting light brown head. The aroma was roasted malt, coffee,  vanilla, and nuts. The mouthfeel was full bodied, and creamy. The flavour was roasted malt, smoked wood, and hints of  coffee. The whisky appears in the finish.  I actually enjoyed this one more than the 16 year and 18 year versions.

0.33l bottle from Cracked Kettle. Finally! Have been looking forward to this for almost a year now (since the last time I tastes my first Ola Dubh). This one pours a really dark almost black and oily body with a small light bubbly and lacing tanned head. Its aroma is sweet, has notes of wool, mild wood, some concentrated caramel and hints of cardboard, chocolate and vanilla. It has a oily mouthfeel, average carbonation and its medium to full-bodied. Tastes really nice. This oily beer has some light sweet flavors along with some licorice, woody oak, tar and its quite peaty. Not so much whisky notes as the 16 had (the only one Ive tasted) Ends in a light warming and sweet finish along with some thin notes of smoke and whisky. Not as epic and whisky-like as I remember it, but damn, I just love the Ola Dubh series!

330ml bottle from Sainsburys. Pours a black colour with a large tan head that dies away. Aroma of whiskey up front with oak, treacle and molasses. Flavour of whiskey again with woody, caramel and chocolate notes. Plenty of dark malt, oily mouth-feel. Not but but a little thin.

Bottle at Sainsburys. It pours opaque black, with a thin bubbly tan head. The nose is soy sauce, rich chocolate, coffee, clay, salted liquorice and earth. The taste is rich coffee, salted liquorice, pepper, tar, bitter chocolate, astringency, wood, vanilla, peat and earth, with a roasted malt finish. It is full bodied and has moderate carbonation. Its a quality beer, but is perhaps a bit too savoury to be great.
Geweldig bier! Prachtig bier met zeer complexe smaak. Whiskey, rook, chocolade en mout. Iets voller en steviger en hij zou perfect zijn. Lekker met een stukje Blue Stilton.

Tasted on 8/18/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at Binnys Lincoln Park, botled in July 2009.  Pours an opaque, nearly black, dark brown with an average tan head that slowly recedes to very thin whispy lace and a nice collar.  The nose is full of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, oak, with some light baking spices, lightly peaty smoke, char, and Scotch.  The flavor is very well balanced with some light vanilla up front, moving to the more roasted coffee, dark chocolate, very dry oak, nutty Scotch, lightly smokey peat, and some charred notes.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and charred peaty scotch finish.

(Bottle) Appearance is absolutely black with a nice tan head. It has a lovely complex aroma of malt overlaid with vanilla and whiskey. The palate is full bodied, oily, creamy with a nice tingle of carbonation. The flavour is extraordinary with sweet toffee and dark caramel overlaid with a fine whiskey taste that builds towards a finish with some refined bitterness and a lasting whiskey taste. An exceptional beer that integrates the whiskey element seemlessly.

Bottle, brewed Feb 2010.
Black with a porous light brown head.
A fantastic aroma with great whisky notes, chocolate, licorice and toffee.
Taste: whisky, toffee, ashes, chocolate, a light smokiness, licorice, hints of peat. Good, but doesnt match the aroma.
Above medium-bodied, smooth.
Really nice.
Bouteille 330 ml. 8.0%. Couleur brune foncée, noire. Mousse beige. Arômes de chocolat, malt, whisky. En bouche, douce, alcool et notes de malt grillé, chocolat et whisky. Excellente.
Bottle. Dark. Scotch, of course. Malty. Chocolate. A little bitter. Very nice offering.

Pours jet-black with a one finger, off-white head. On the nose is dark fruits, plums, raisins, black cherries, sherry, vanilla, caramel, toffee, roasted malts, chocolate, chocolate-orange, coffee liqueur, smoke, and wood. Mouth feel is thick and oily with low to medium carbonation. Taste is very dark, rich and reminiscent of a stout with roasted malts, leather, tobacco, dark chocolate, coffee, whisky, smoke, dark fruits, oak, grassy/floral hops, burnt almonds, caramel,  green apples, vanilla and the faintest hint of peat. Finish is long, dry and dark leaving dark chocolate, bitter coffee, and a touch of ash/smoke. The Highland Park influence is quite obvious although the heather-honey character is not as present as I would have imagined. No matter though, an outstanding brew!

aged in 12 yr old single malt scotch whisky casks, individually numbered and dated on the bottle (#12124, Feb 2010). Contains barley, oats and wheat. Pours jet black, beautiful micro foam head, lacing clings to the glass. Incredible roasted malts and deep whisky tones on the nose. Burst of roasted coffee, dark tamed soft bitter malts, oaty cerealness, a bit of balanced hops, and hints of dark chocolate. This is an AMAZING beer. Opulent in complexity, hits several areas on the palate, crisp with good body. It drinks like a semi-sweet bitter roasted coffee & chocolate, yet potent, smooth, and refreshing. Cant wait to try the 16 and 30 reserve.

11.2 oz. bottle, bottled in july 2009, first of four (12, 16, 30, and 40)-Pours almost pitch black with a little brown showing on the edges when held up to the light, the head started with about 1 finger then quickly dissipated to a collar and a few eyeballs of foam. The aroma is very rich, it smells like a candy bar that has been soaking in whiskey, and a very nice oaky aroma. The flavor is rich bitter sweet chocolate, whiskey, oak, and raisins. The body is full, actually thick and almost chewy, carbonation is low, this beer lingers on the tongue, leaving you fully satisfied but wanting more. Wonderfully complex, next up the 16.

33 cl bottle, BBE 201Z (sic!). Rated on 24.6.2011
Tasting of all Ola Dubh versions from 12 to 40 and Old Engine Oil as a reference. This was the second best beer in the session.
Aroma has vanilla and lots of whisky barrel. The whisky is somewhat pungent, but still kind of nice. Flavour has lots of peated whiskey and behind that one can observe a hint of roasted malt too. Very enjoyable stuff.

Appearance - black, slight ruby edges on glass. 1 finger tan head, good lacing on glass, very vicous 4
Aroma - Complex big beer, heavy roasted malts, cask wood, leaves, smoke, chocolate, bit earthy, savoury notes, alcohol well hidden. 
Taste - Complex mix of sweet and savoury roasted malts, dark chocolate, smoked cask wood, bit of bovril, leaves, light espresso, alcohol hidden although is 8%.
palate - Smooth silky mouthfeel, coating the mouth with a complex warming finish of cask wood, light smoke and slight bitter chocolate.
Overall - One of the very best ales from Scotland. Great stuff. However, the versions aged in older casks are more complex.
Bottle from Alko Arkadia. Originally rated on 12.6.2009. Great barrel aged beer, but not quite as good as the best of the series.

A taste of this beer left me suspended in momentary shock, awe and excitement. Im not a big Whiskey fan, in fact I avoid it. But this... I could feel roasted chocolate with a very noticeable Whiskey taste, and all I could think was "well, they got me into Whiskey now". It has a high alcoholic content, and this shows through in the taste. Not unpleasantly so, but just enough to remind you that youre holding a powerful drink, and just like Whiskey, you must drink it with class. Almost black in colour, with a tan head, it even looks delicious. Medium to full bodied, quite slick. Such an amazing experience!

Pours a luscious opaque sable with a respectable pale tan head that leaves a little lacing. Strong aroma has an overtone of honey and hints of caramel, wood and malt. Flavor has caramel, malty and woody tones with nutty, woody and honey hints and a touch of yeast. Texture is thick and smooth and just a little tingly, but still pleasing and beer-like.
Dark brown with a small brown head.  Malty and fruity tones. Malt, fruit and oak. Full body with long, very balanced aftertaste.

Bottle pours very dark brown thick liquid with brief but decent tan head.  Didnt pick up much aroma, mainly roast and malts.  Malty taste with slight roast, some chocolate and vanilla, peat.  Whiskey comes and goes.  Palate full without being sticky.  Long finish of malts with slight roast.  Alcohol apparent but not overwhelming.
As the description says it is interesting, but there are more interesting barrel-aged beers than this out there..

Shared a bottle with DutchDrebus on one of our evenings tasting together. Color was obviously very black, smell was pretty nice. Taste was soft, but a great mouthfeel with enough carbonation. Very nice long finish. Very very nice to drink, lovely.

Bottle. Very dark brown, pretty much black with thin pale brown head. Aroma of whisky, some smoke, wood. Whisky in flavour but quite mellow, some chocolate, some alcohol. Its very nice and would like to try again.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 220511.
Black with brown head. Aroma of intense malt (smokelike). Flavor with roasted palate.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours black with a foamy caramel head. Aroma of syrup or molasses, roasted caramel, booze, dark chocolate. Flavour of coffee, dark chocolate, wood, a slight metallic feel to it. Not really sweet at all as the nose would suggest. Quite complex and nicely balanced.

12 oz. bottle, pours black with a medium beige head. Aroma of wood, scotch, butterscotch, sweet dark fruits and caramel. Flavour brings out a fair bit of wood, scotch barrels, smoke / peat, with secondary notes of dark fruits and caramel. Most excellent.
Poured dark as oil and enjoyed about as much.  Smelled of black olives and tasted like peat and earth.  Leaves a nice malty aftertaste.  Pairs well with moldy cheese, like stilton.
Very black type of beer. Smells a bit earth-like, nature. Taste is okay, not to agressive. Mouthfeel is quite nice.

Bottle 20307 of Sept. 2007.  Pours to a pitch black body with a very lively dark tan head.  The aroma could be smelled during pour from 2 feet away.  Chocolate and treacle with certain notes of Highland Park 12: mossy peat with honey and marshmallow.  The flavor is chocolate, peat, marshmallow, heather honey, and violets.  Some salt to round it out.  The scotch is definitely there and rather dominates the beer.  But, it does round it out pretty well.  Medium body with a lingering oily component, likely from the scotch barrel.

330 mL bottle. Bottle date: September 2007. Drank June 2011. 

APPEARANCE: Black.

Hues of espresso brown. 

Head is practically inexistent; just some thin and sparse large bubbles. 


AROMA: Toasted and roasted malts, whiskey that appears to have hardly any smoky character, dark bitter chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel, wood, soy sauce.

Hints of earthy character. 


TASTE: Coffee, earthy, licorice, earthy-ish whiskey, herbal notes, dark bitter chocolate, soy sauce. Roast bitterness on finish. 

Soy sauce hints more prevalent than preferred. 


MOUTH FEEL: Thinner than expected, yet fairly boozy from the whiskey. 


OVERALL: Like a café Americano with a splash of whiskey, a dash of rich soil (ie, pleasant earthiness), and an unpleasant accidental drop of soy sauce.  

Expected a bit more. Perhaps past its prime, given this bottle was nearly 4 years old. To be fair, recently had Port Brewings Older Viscosity, which I greatly enjoyed, so may have had higher expectations than I should have for this beer.
Dark with fast disappearing Brown head. Lots of chocolate and burne malt. Some whisky is there but not overwhelming.
Dark brown pour, off-white/tannish head.  Sweet malts, smoke, light chocolate and fruit, scotch, and light peat.  Oily mouth feel.  Pretty enjoyable.
330ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a large, thick mocha head.  Aroma is peat and Islay whiskey.  Taste is a bit watery to start.  Mild peat and whiskey on the finish.
Pours dark, small head, nice smokey nose with slight chocolate overtones. Taste is well balanced smokiness never overpowering. Evening drink by the fire.

Is a black, oily pour out of the bottle. Burnt aromas, chocolate, peat and smoke. Starts with a sweet touch of scotch and becomes more dry-roasted chocolate bitterness on the finish. Full-bodied and low carbonation. Nice.

assolutamente particolare e pretenziosa.con profumi tostati e di whisky.in bocca molto persistente con ancora sentori di caffe, frutta matura oltre che carruba e vaniglia estratta dalla botte poi ciccolato, insomma una sequenza spaventosa di sapori.anche se non è la mia birra non puoi non giudicarla male.

Out of a bottle at Martins West in Redwood City.  Very-brown, almost black with brown flecks around all sides. Brown head. Tar and peat aroma. Amazing flavor of rich peat and whiskey barrel. Smokiness lingers long on this. I taste this well over a minute after taking a sip. So complex.

Reviewed from notes.

Served in a tulip glass. Pours a very dark brown color with a thin head. A bit persistent with some carbonation bubbles throughout. Nose is light whisky plus some oak, vanilla, dark fruits, and smoke. A bit of roast. The taste has some whisky and peat smoke plus a bit of roast and oak. Good body and not too boozy. Drinkability is higher on this than the 30 and 40.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

Bottle. Darker khaki head that retains quite well, nearly black.  Roasted malt, oak, peat, chocolate, and smoke in the aroma.  Flavor is very whisky-driven, but really enjoyed that aspect since there was a lot of nice peat on top of the roasted maltiness.  Lots of chocolate comes through, viscous body.  Nice.

Bottle. Innisfil, Ontario, Canada.
I run the risk of being thrashed for writing this, but I didnt really enjoy this beer. Pours jet black with a thin head and looks good, but the aroma is a suckerpunch; like a shot of whiskey. Goes down like syrup. Chocolate taste, some oak, less whiskey going down than on the nose which was a good thing. Gets sweet - sickly so - as I continued towards the end. Monster oak finish. Very interesting and exciting to try, but not something Id want regularly.
Moderately sharp malt alcohol aroma.Black color with a medium brown airy head. Light sweet beginning quickly becoming slightly bitter with a mild tangy finish.
Great beer. slightly oily palate buth with the right amount of bitterness. Coffeegrinds, slight sweetness. Very surprising and great. From a friend who bought it at the Bierkoning.

Dark black. Small tan head. Some lacing. Coffee and chocolate nose. Alcohol and wood. Chocolate taste with a good amount of vanilla and a slight roastiness. Velvety smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Nice sweetness that almost tastes like a chocolate milk with alcohol and roasted grains. Great beer.

Beautiful black coffee appearance even though the head disappears quite quickly. Beautiful treacle, tar and burnt wood on the nose. The palate is quite drying, there are more burnt flavours and it has huge length. Big structure, fairly thick in texture but not cleaning on the end. Definitely a digestif beer.

July 2009 vintage. 11.2 oz black foiled bottle with a little information tag.

IT pours a dark brown/black, the head is a greyish/brownish/tan and it is nicely foamy. It recedes pretty quickly with not much lacing.

The smell is very smooth and subtle. It isnt an over the top bourbon bomb in the nose. It has notes of chocolate, peat, scotch, and wood.

The scotch is intensified in the flavor as it almost takes center stage. It has a lot of peatiness, smoke, and barrel notes. There are also notes of tobacco and earthiness. It is a very earthy, organic tasting brew. The sweetness of the brew gets more intense as you go. It tastes very rustic.

It is pretty good, I wonder if the other editions would be better or worse, or any different.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010 05:29:37

Mustaa moottoriöljyähän tämä on. Tuoksusta löytyy karamellia, suklaata, lakritsia ja etenkin soijaa. Maultaan Ola Dubbi 12 on pitkälti samaa. Soijaa ei tietenkään maussa tosin ole. Mukavan runsas olut, jonka voisi ottaa lasiinsa uudestaankin.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2011 black, thin dark tan head, looks syrupy in the glass
soft dark choc taste but more oak and alcohol notes. some raw grain hints as well
med/thin body and softly fizzy, clightly syrupy
almost over oaked. its not but there is a lot of oak and it overpowers most of the beer.

very dark. slightly fizzy w/ thin head
smells sweet and treakle
pretty nice. treakle is dominant flavour but slightly fizzy instead of syrupy

Pours dark brown almost black with virtually no head at all.  After the pour, there is a ring of mocha colored foam around the ring of the glass and slight hints of lacing.  A very slight and thin wisp of foam covers a fraction of the glass.  Aroma of alcohol, licorice, Taste is smoky and the scotch whisky is very noticeable in the palate and aftertaste.  Smoky, peat feel and also chest warming alcohol.  This is a beer that would taste best by the fire on a winter night, after a good meal.  My bottle number was 16317 and it was bottled in November, 2008.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2015 It has a very strong barleywine/english strong ale aroma to it, but in the flavor has a very peaty malt base that dominates.  Thankfully the scotch flavor doesnt come into play, although the smokiness is very strong, which in the end makes it a great old ale.
33 Bottle in Klooster, Delft.  Tried alongside the 30 year - Both the whiskey smell an flavour is far more subdued in the 12 year.  Lovely beer

0,33 l bottle, Biererei, Vienna.
Black in body as night in the countryside...Fantastic creamy beige-brown head that never disappeares fully, allury laces on the surface. Cocoa and rum, vanilla and burnt woods, tobacco and dried dark fruits in the liqueric nose. Complex aroma...and flavor too. Smooooth mouthfeel, fine carbonation with microbubbles in the oily but light body. Light vinous character lurking behind the fruity character. Plum comes with some cocoa, figs and tobacco, rum taste with some mild hops, vanilla with woods. Tannins and mild smoke in the aftertaste. Veryvery good, noble one.We have a 40...I have a concern about this...
Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Sweet and roasty aroma with some nice boozy whiskey-like notes. The flavor has sweet malts, roast, chocolate, leather, and whiskey. Downright delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Way more noticeable notes of scotch than in the 18 year.  Actually tastes a bit like someone poured scotch into a lighter bodied stout.  Good beer, not really old ale-like for me.

$8 for 11.2oz bottle
Bottled Sept 2007 Sampled Nov 2008

A vigorous pour barely coaxes a head out of this solid black beer. Heavy aroma of vanilla some roasted malts, chocolate and some scotch. I love the aroma its very enticing. Taste is chocolate and roasted malts, faint scotch and ash. Lingering roasted malt bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel is creamy smooth. Body is medium Carbonation is adequate. Great smelling and tasting brew. I would have liked the body a bit thicker, but great just the same. Subtle, not over whiskeyd.

12oz bottle thanks to I dont remember who.
Appearance : Pitch black with a medium sized head (I forced it a bit). Head is brown and creamy. Nice lacing.

Aroma : Intense roasted malt and liquorice. Light notes of ashes and wood. Light peaty smoke. Notes of chocolate and coffee too. Light hops. Resinous and oily hops.

Taste : Roasted malt and woody smoke. Dark chocolate and liquorice. Light ashes. Finish rather bitter with notes of alcohol. Quite warm on the finish. Palate is very smooth. Texture is silky. Long chocolat-y and ashy finish. Resinous and oily hops.

Overall : Very nice stuff. Very complex both on aroma and taste. Awesome palate. Great sipper. A little bit too hot on the finish. Gets less hot as it breathes a bit more. I really like this beer style.

Appearance: solid oily black, espresso cream head is thin and delicious looking  thin, tightly packed and a bubbly collar. Swirls into a thin filmy puddle, crema collar.

Nose: oily, smoky, licorice, black root. Sweet leather underneath and leather oils, oily wood. Charcoal, earth, smoke, ash. Chunks of fudge, truffles. Tobacco leaf, cigars. Marshmallow mingles with the fudge for some rocky road action.

Palate: creamy, silky, and oily mouthfeel. Fudges, melted caramels, truffles, turtles. Warmth of melted caramel and nougat in the back. Tar and ash in the finish, lingers on the top back of tongue. Brownies and more fudge. Tobacco leaf rounds it out with some spice, dirt, tobacco leaf, black earth and roots. Immediate and lingering warmth in breath. Leather in back and underneath, lightly raw wood cask quality.

Final Thoughts: quite tasty though of all the Ola Dubh from Harvieston, I found this one (obviously so) to be the youngest. A little rough around the edges but thats also part of its charm.

330 mL bottle.  Pours black without much of a head; whats there is light tan.  Heavy, syrupy aromas of molasses, raisin, smoke, and dark chocolate.  Smokey, peaty Scotch leads the flavor strongly, backed up with cocoa, coffee, raisin, and molasses.  This is quite the lovely beer.  Certainly Ill be trying the other versions in the future.
Outstanding aroma with hints of the whiskey barrels.  Rich black color.  Taste is malty with hints of whisky, but not overpowering.  Like drinking a good porter out of a glass just used for scotch.

Bouteille de 330 ml achetée chez LCBO (Ottawa, ONT). Arôme: Odeur de céréales grillées avec une pointe de chocolat et de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat avec une pointe de vanille et de fumée. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de vanille en arrière goût. (Rating #3472)

Nose: Very discreet, just a little hint of cask
Taste: Very dry taste, a lot of cask and discreet liquorish

Pours very dark, almost opaque black with a thin tan head.  Aromas are rich with chocolate and vanilla, deep roasted coffee, some wood, smoke and a nice hint of peat.  Its really a heavy thick aroma and it smells great!  Nice full flavors of chocolate and bitter coffee.  The finish has a touch of smoke and peat and it lingers for a long time.  The mouthfeel is a rather thin, but its not bad.

Rich black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, oak, coffee, & some vanilla; Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, dark fruit, and hops; Finish is smooth with some smoke; Very nicely balanced; Overall, well done - very good.

Bottle, from trade with Papsoe. An oily, quite flat beer, next to black in color, and topped by a small tan head. Some whiskey and hints on the nose which is mostly roasted malts and alcohol. Sweet and warming in the mouth, with peat and roasted malts. Oily and full-bodied, finishing roasted and warming. A quite nice one, goes well with the Christmas pudding I had with the 12, 16 and 30 years Ola Dubhs. None of them are really impressive though, but fine beers they are. 100827

330ml bottle. Looks thick and black in the glass with chocolate coloured foam head. Chocolate aroma with a hint of whisky that gets into the nose . Flavour is full with a chocolate bite and velvet mouthfeel and a kick of alcohol.

Bottle #13297, brewed February 2010. 33 cL from the LCBO courtesy of Rob and Pat, served in a snifter. Pours black with a medium light brown head. The head fades slowly to a bare cover but leaves lots of fine lace. On the nose, there are aromas of charred malts, espresso, chocolate, molasses, cask wood and whisky. The flavour is moderately sweet with complex notes of molasses, roasted malts, espresso and cask wood. Whisky notes arise midway through and endure to the finish; there is also a note of herbal hops. The finish is lingering roasted malts with a huge whisky quality. On the palate, it is full in body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice sweet roasty ale with a whisky accent in the latter half. It is deep, complex and very smooth, without a hint of harshness. Very well done--I look forward to the others in the series! 2010-12-25

Bottle.  Pours an opaque black with a thick, lasting brown head.  Mild woody aroma (oak).  Taste: Malty, some roast.  Notes of toffee, chocolate, coffee, some earthy bitterness, very warming mouthfeel, full-bodied.  Finishes with a burnt oak / earthy bitterness.  One of the best oaked beers Ive had to date.

Pours a very dark brown with no head at all.  The aroma is strong with roasted malt and alcohol with sugary notes.  I like the complexity.  The taste is slightly bitter and sour but smooth.  This beer is full-bodied and thick and finishes dry.  I was not sure what to expect, but its really good.  You can feel the alcohol coming though.

Bottle, bought from Good Food Company, Colchester. 

Thick creamy lacing, opaque colour, really jet black, aroma is pure massive Highland Park, stunning aroma, really complex, Highland Park whiskey, oak, vanilla, strong cheese, wood, peat and smoke. Stunning aroma. Love this. 

The taste is rich thick vanilla, toffee, coffee, rich roasted malts, some refined liquorish, peat, smoke, somewhat lacking in body compared to the other ranges but generally speaking very balanced, very complex, brilliantly mixed and excellent coffee espresso bitter finish which is also fruity, with red peppers and plenty of bags of booze and whiskey. 

A really enjoyable beer and much more sessionable than others of the series but definitely lacks something. Fantastic aroma and the taste is a tad lacking but a good beer either way,
33cl, Bottle N°04008, at 8%Vol, new exclusive Scottish brew Anno 2008, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex Porter, not too heavy, balanced, clear, small head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Bottle 16550, from September 2007.  Pours deep red, appearing black in the glass, with a thin brown head.  Aromas of dark raisins, toffee, buttery oak, apple, and bourbon.  Sweet apple flavor with raisin, oaky caramel, and a toffee finish with a hint of bitter grass and alcohol.  Smooth, medium body, creamy, and warming.  A good, very smooth beer, but not as great as I had hoped.  Too bad I cant afford the 30 or 40 year old editions.

Now a year old bottle from the last of my case. Dark with gold highlights, big scotchy and toffee aromas. Taste plays out aromas and there is a long silky feel that was not there a year ago. Either Ive gotten used to it or its gotten better over time.

Lovely looking thing, near black, good size light brown foamy head with some big bubbles.  Great retention.  Aromas: chocolate, prune, raisin, tobacco.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel reveals wood, alcohol.  Finish lasts forever.  Astonishingly complex.  Wonderful.

Bottle at home. Pitch black pour, thin tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, some vanilla, coffee, chocolate and licorice. Flavor is bitter dry tobacco, some coffee, a hint of sweetness, roasted malts and some bready yeast. Slightly watery texture and low carbonation. Very nice stuff.

12/2/10.  11.2oz bottle courtesy daknole!  Black pour with some browns/reds when held to the light with basically no head except a small ring of brown fluff.  Dark fruit and molasses aroma with a hint of tannin and alcohol in there.  The flavor starts similarly sweet but packs a nice bitter roasted/coffee punch that lingers nicely with a hint of wood.  Not bad!

33 cl bottle, pours dark with a decent creamy head, pretty flat, aroma of roasted coffee, peat, ash, butter and booze, taste is roasted coffee, peat, chocolate, ash and whiskey, ok finish, good but not great.
smells like honey and beef.  tastes like overripe bananas.  some caramel and cardboard too. not too much alcohol flavor at all for such a big beer. pair with......man, i dont know, cheerios?

(330ml bottle #14381 September 2007 vintage) opaque espresso brown, spare tan head. Nose of vanilla, espresso, fudge, sweet subtle peat/whisky. Taste of strong smoky peat, dry cocoa, fudgey although not richly so, and a good amount of woody notes. Body is thinner than expected, and overall I wish it was less smokey/bacon and more chocolaty. Even so, quite a nice beer.

Smells sweeter than I would have expected... or liked for that matter.

No problem however as just looking at this deep mahogany brew with its small chocolate--brown head amped up my thirst.  Taste is of sweet malts, with just a hint of whiskey. Alcohol is nicely hidden, but the lingering sweetness hung around a bit too long.
Draft: pours dark black with a whisp of tan head, malty, chocolate, slightly bitter, very flat - not sure I care for the lack of carbonation in my beers.

Bottle aged for 1 year. Pours a black color with some reddish notes in the bottom of the glass. The head is frothy and tan, with a sord of dusty look to it. Aroma is of whiskey, dusty old oak, roasted malt, dark fruit and alcohol. Flavor quite sweet with alot of whiskey and oak along with some earthy hops, roasted malt, darkfruit like raisins and plum, whiskey soaked dark fruit, chocolate, oak, alcohol and some subtle smoke. The body is full with a creamy mouthfeel. Overall a really good old ale. I would love to try some of the older Ola Dubhs.

Bottle. Pours Opaque black with nice tan head and nice lacing. Distinct single malt sweetness on the nose; some floral , resinous hop aroma mocha notes, nutty and a touch of roast. Medium-Full bodied, Nice slick mouthfeel; complex flavours; medium-light carbonation. Pleasant; sweet, light lactic finish with a lingering chocolate and some hints of single malt complexity. Pleasing, interesting and complex.

An inky pour, that is indeed as black as engine oil, lifts a solid mocca head; this falls quickly and leaves not much lacing.  The nose wears its barrel aging on its sleeve, giving up peat, ash, vanilla, wood, chocolate and coffee.  And theres all the roasted malt youd expect of an imperial stout.  In the mouth this all continues to a honeyed, hoppy end.  The whiskey and peat is soft, with all of the edges being very rounded - almost to the point of my wanting just one discordant flavour to give it a bit of oomph.  But it wears its sweet simplicity well, finishing with a certain coffee note.  The peat disappears quickly, although a creamy vanilla remains.  As this is the 12 year old, I imagine everything grows in boldness and complexity as the series continues.  So its a good start.

Bottle. Dark brown, almost black pour, thin foamy head. Distinct aromas of dry roasted malt and smoky, woody scotch. Taste is super well balanced - the sweetness is dimmed down just enough by the salty, peaty scotch flavors. Palate is almost flat but very well suited to this beer. I love these old ales.
2008 Vintage.  I love it.  I guess I will have to stick with beers aged in whiskey barrels.

Bottle.

Normally I am not the biggest fan of "whisky-beers" but this one was really pleasant. Nice aroma and taste of whisky, smoke, roasted malt, licorice and some dark chocolate. Nice full body.

Bottle at Cardinals Porter Symposium. 
Clear deep amber with a tanned film. Faint whisky aroma with vanilla present. Rich roasted flavours along with alcohol, sweetness, acidity and with a whisky hint again. Medium to full body. Gentle carbonation. Excellent!

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2010 2008 Bottle. Poured a charred brown (about as close to black as you can get) with some motor oil brown around the edges - no head, just a few bubbles around the edges. Aroma was big & mellow: rye, whiskey, wood, mild roasted malts, smoke, licorice/chocolate. Taste: huge rye and sweet roasted malts, nice mellow notes of smoke, wood, whiskey, licorice/chocolate. The Rye in the aroma and taste really leans towards black olives to me. Thinnish body. Finish: smoke, roasted malts, wood and a slight alcohol warming. Overall: very, very good - perfect brew for a cool fall night.
Smokey aroma with hints of blueberries and dried meat, such as pastrami.  Chalky and dry taste with hints of chocolate

Bottle. Pours a black beer with a weak offwhite/beige head. The aroma is malt, roasted, licorice, wood and vanilla. The flavor is malt, roasted, licorice and vanilla. The palate is smooth with sweetness. Overall a good beer.
aroma of blueberries, tar, coffee and light smokiness. taste is chalky, salty and smoked (almost smoked sausages). smooth mouthfeel. very nice.

Thick dark pour medium carbonation aroma liccorice chocolate rich molasses vanilla that oat influence flavour medium ibu aoat and wheat smooth tasting rich chocolate molasses vanilla very smooth rewarding taste finish smooth alround malt flavour medium to mild bitter a lasting goodness mildly dry

Bottled sample via Savvy1982, Near black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of whisksy, stewed fruit, caramel, chocolate, and ash. A nice blend of roasted malt, smokey scotch, and caramel notes in the mouth. Substantial body, but not at the expense of drinkability. Could have been a bit smokier overall for my taste, but this is some nice stuff.

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 19.4.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small beige head. Aroma of peat, roasted malts and of course whisky. Pleasant aroma, something different. Flavour of roasted malts, smoke, whisky and oak. Full bodied with oily texture and soft carbonation. Very nice Old Ale.

Bottle. Thick black pour with a short tan head that quickly shrinks to a ring. Aroma has roasty and lactic characteristics as well as notes of dark chocolate, coffee beans, licorice and vanilla. Whisky notes are more noticeable in the flavour with hints of peat, oak, seaweed and smoke mixed with roast malt, licorice and bitter chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with low carbonation and a lingering roasty, bitter finish. Very good. One of the best barrel aged beers I have tried; it integrates well without dominating, and really adds to the complexity of the whole.

Black, tan head that fades to a coat then lasts. Lovely aroma of peat, vanilla, roasted malt, oats, heather, chocolate, almonds, fruity whisky. Silky oatmeal texture. Smells more together than it tastes. Tastes strongly of Highland Park (havent had it since the 80s, but I last drank it around the time I started going out with my wife, so I remember it well enough). This mixes well but is not integrated with and almost overwhelms a beer that has light roast, chocolate and vanilla. Delicious, but I wish the whisky had melded with a beer a bit more - maybe a bit of a age would help. As it is its a lovely mixture rather than a harmonious beer.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, smoke and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, smoke, chocolate and liquorish.

Bottle at Bondekonen Ølmesse 2010.
Dark red-brown with an off-white head. Aroma heavy malty (hard roasted, burnt, notes of whisky, smoke and wood). Flavor heavy sweet, moderate spicy and bitter. Full body, low carbonated. Very fine.

Bottle [330ml]. Bottle No. 45278, July 2009. This has been in my fridge for a while and I was certain Id rated it, Im glad I decided to check, turns out I hadnt. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size slowly-diminishing frothy tan head. Aroma: Oh boy, that smells nice! Sweet with roasted dark malt, wood, some scotch and vanilla notes, some chocolate, dark fruit and more -- complex aroma with lots there. Flavour follows the aroma, very nice and complex, with light roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, some scotch, vanilla and dark fruit as well as alcohol and some peat -- its surprisingly easy to drink. Medium to full bodied. A fantastic beer, Ive loved all the Ola Dubhs Ive had so far.

Whisky and some vanilla on the nose as well as burnt toast. The palate hits hard and complex with liqorice swirling through dark chocolate, roast, creamy cocoa butter, and some vaporous alcohol. Oddly, the whisky notes so present in the nose are harder to detect on the palate. The finish is long and faintly sweet, and its here that you get some of the spicy and gently fruity notes of the Highland Park 12. Just a touch of applewood as it finally fades away. Delicious.

This is complex! Smells like dark warm malts and a barrel, sweet sugars from the malts come off in the warm water... you could have a sit in the aroma and reminisce. Some licorice in the nose too. Tastes very dark and sweet, Fades out so nicely, smooth, the % is there but you can hardly even tell.

Bottle. Pours medium black, mildly transparent at the edges. Nose is ash, caramel, milk chocolate, ash, tobacco, man this smells both thick and awesome! Flavours deliver! Sweet pipe tobacco, soya sauce, cocoa, coffee, dear God this kicks ass! Freaking stunned with this one. Not what I was expecting at all, especially compared to the 30yr. Delicious.

Bottle. Deep, hearty, near-black with a brown, lumbering, get-there-on-my-own-time head. Rich aroma of dark chocolate, black rye bread, char, whiskey, fig paste, molasses, and soft vanilla. Palate is velvet! Sweet and chocolatey, with equal weight given to flavours of fig paste, vanilla, light scotch, light wood, light ash, and a trailing spiciness and earthiness. Crazy good.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
A: snifter. pours an abyss-like black. nice dark tan head. decent retention rate and mild lacing.

S: some sourness in the nose. tons of roasted malts, coffee, toffee, and some cocoa. some fruit hints, berries mostly.

T: a lot of dark berries, some peat flavors. dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and some toffee. some whiskey qualities.

M: medium to heavy bodied. low carbonation level. very mellow.

D: very smooth ans enjoyable. solid wood aged beer. well worth getting the first of this series. it was aged a year in the cellar as well.
Bottle.Pours jet black with a beige head.Aroma of peat,roasted malt,sweet malt and alcohol.Flavor is sweet malt,roasted malt ,whiskey and caramel.Full body,soft carbonation.Nice !

Pours out an inky black brew with a dark brown ring and minimal lacing. Wow! The aroma is phenomenal. Chocolate, brandy, a roast quality that comes in second to the chocolate, daaaark cherry, dates or figs or something or not, molasses, lots o nuts maybe similar to toasted almonds, oak, sweet raisiny spice.... I might just smell this until it evaporates. The taste is wonderful! Roasty burnt initial impression followed by dark chocolate, some booze, creeping bitterness, ashes, vanilla, salt? what the hell?, wood, the pic of the pith hat with all the shitty beer caps glued on from ebay. Viscous, smooth, oily, thick = awesome. Theres a spot in my heart for these whisky cask brews that are not named Innis & Gunn.
Bottle. Thick, dark and rich. a beautiful aromatic brew. Oak, chocolate with the Highland Park Whisky in the nose and in the taste. A great balance between the flavor charaterisics..
33 cl bottle. black with small lasting light brown head. Flavour is roasted malt, liquorice, peated whiskey, chocolate and coffee.

Bottle. Thick and dark with a lasting bronw head and lacing. Aroma of rich dark "oil"; peat whisky and malt. Rich thick brown ale strong porter front evolves into a tasty alcohol laced whisky licorice malty tasty.

Pours black with a reddish hue in the light.  Very thin brown head. Aroma of scotch and oak fill the room once opened. Subtle aroma of dark fruit is also preasent.  Strong roasted malt flavour acompanied by oack and chocolate. A sweet fruity finish lingers in the mouth and eventually gives way to a bitter chocolate aftertaste. This is one hell of a beer. It really brings out the character of the Highland park 12 without detracting from the stout. this beer is incredibly well balanced, just amazing. I cant wait to try the 18!
Bottle at parents house. Pours very dark with a little thing brown head. Thick pleasant taste.

Colour: Black and thick. Nose: Rich sea salt with some marine fish, freshly baked rye bread, creamy milk chocolate. All of these were fairly faint I might add. Taste: Deeply roasted malt leads to smoked oak, salted butter, molases, finish is bitter-sweet with some pure vanilla extract. Thick palate. Lots of powerful and unique characteristics but they seem just a touch lost. Still, tasty stuff.

Appearence - pours a slick jet black, small tan-couloured head. Aroma - awesome complex nose, roasty, with dark chocolate, dark fruits, scotch, molasses, touch of caramel, vanilla, peat, wood. Palate/Flavour - body is solid, slick, viscous, flavours of smoky peat, scotch, dark fruits, bitter chocolate, very long lasting toasty tart peaty finish. Overall - a fantastic brew, would like to try the 40 year version

Pours an opaque dark brown with just a few sparse bubbles of light tan head with a thin line around the edge of the glass.  Rich smoky barrel and chocolate with some hints of peat and malty scotch.  Flavor is dark chocolate and coffee with light scotch notes.  Thin

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a clear, deep bronze body with a medium, off-white fluffy head that sticks around for a while. Nose is complex: dark malts, grain, licorice and wood. Taste is equally complex; a nice and rich blend of toasted bread, licorice and whiskey barrel oak notes. Nicely balanced tones of hop bitterness lingering in the finish along with roasted malts. Ola Dubh is indeed a very smooth and delicious Old Ale from Scotland.

clear dark brown, smooth very nice looknig light brown head that doesnt stay for very long.
aroma of roasted grains, english licorice, whiskey, wood.
flavor is roasted stuff, lots of salty licorice, some english licorice, some whiskey, some wood,

A - Roasted chocolate and caramel aroma, with hints of scotch
A - Black with creamy brown head
T - Slightly sweet with full, but controlled bitter finish
P - Soft and creamy
O - Wow...this may be the best beer I have ever tasted. The search may be over.....
Pretty insane stuff. The aroma is straight up bourbon and oak. The ABV is only 8% but it makes you think twice, if I didnt know the ABV I would have guessed 11 or 12 %. Its damn good.

Bottle from Sept 2007. Pours black with a thin and very bubbly head. Aroma is of dark malts and scotch. Taste is very smooth and tastes as if its a nice blend of a stout with hints of scotch and sweetness to it. Very good, much better than I expected.

Shared with Jim at the Anderson, Fortrose.
Excellent whicky cask aged stout from one of the best Scottish breweries. Beautiful marriage of the honeyish, slightly peaty Highland Park notes with the roasty stout notes. Much better integration of flavour than I find from many similar whisky cask stouts.

Notes: 12 oz bottle, 2007 vintage poured into a snifter.
Pours a deep oily brown hue with a nice brown head. The nose is peat, smoke, oak, scotch whiskey, and chocolate. The taste is big on the smokey, rich flavors of the scotch and the oakiness of the barrels. The chocolate comes in the middle and finishes with an excellent scotch taste. The mouthfeel is initially moderate-medium bodied but ends up being dry like a nice scotch. A truly great offering from Harviestoun, i;d buy again.

Medium darkish brown head. Opaque black body. Strong chocolatey toffee aroma with notes of cocoa, marzipan, and alcohol. Sweet, powerful chocolatey roasty cocoa taste with toffee and alcohol notes. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Fullish body. Dryish roasty charcoal smoke aftertaste with wooden notes. Lovely peaty smokiness settles in the mouth as you drink. Excellent balance between the bitter and the sweet, and lovely raw whisky smoke character. (0.33l bottle, Cornelius, Edinburgh.)

Bottled. Black coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, liqourice, fruits, light roast and spice. Flavour of chocolate, light ripe fruits, spice, light liqourice and some vague roast. Medium to full bodied. Dry sweet and fruity ligth bitterness in the end. I like this series Ola Dubh series. Very wellmade beers all of them.
Flaske 0,33l. Dyp dyp rød. Nesten svart. Whiskyaroma. Smaken er svakt søtlig. Litt uvariert men gjennomgående whiskypreg. Lett bitter ettersmak. KI=4

Bottle. High creamy and lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Roasted barley malt aroma with whisky choccolate alcohol and wood. Highly carbonated creamy coffee choccolate whisky wood flavor with a nice long and bitter aftertaste.

Pours dark brown with a light brown head.  Smells of roasted malt, vanilla, oak, smoky, ash, leathery, dry.  Tastes dry and peaty with some molasses, vanilla, pepper and chocolate.  Much more distinct than the rest of this series in terms of the Scotch character.

Bottle. Pitch black pour with a creamy dense longlasting tan head leaving very nice lacings. A beauty! The aroma is peaty whisky, chocolate, smoke and sweet tobacco. Lighter notes of ripe fruit. The flavour is heavy peaty, light roasted, some chocolate and caramel and ends up quite whisky peaty like. Me like!
330ml bottle from the LCBO.  A black pour with a hint of dark tan head.  There are roasty, woody aromas, along with a hint of whisky.  Found it to be smooth and rich in flavour.  A nice drink.

This ale poured a deep black colour with a deep brown foamy head. To the nose there are scents of molassass, berries, alcohol, whiskey and smoke. First sip was thick and very flavourful. Flavours of smoke and whiskey along with wine and molassass. Finish is smoke with a little slcohol warming. Palate is smoke with a hint of bitterness.
A tasty, rich flavored dark beer. Like the round fully bodied flavor and the long round and smooth aftertaste.

Dark... near-black with little-to-no head. Seriously. Aroma dark fruit...cherry, oak. In the mouth, much less heavy than expected. Smoke, oak, whiskey, sunflower seed, and slight notes of dark fruit, cocoa, and coffee. Really quite contemplative and enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2010 Bottle. Finally cracked this one I was given for Xmas. Pours a deep black ale in the glass with a small dark cap. Aroma is pungent as it warms in the snifter: Cocoa, roast grains, figs, grass and hints of alcohol.
Chewy malt in front with the roasty-cocoa-coffee tastes but mid palate the complexity hits you> vanilla-oak, pine-honey, cherry figs, spicey hops, raisin bread.....long warm finish. Very decent old ale

Bottle. Pours dark as "Ola Dubh", as promised, with none-to-little head. Roast malts, dark fruits and sugar on the nose, with similar on the tongue. Well balanced overall, with decent complexity and character.

Bottle, Carringtons, Manchester. Poured a murky dense brown colour with a lingering thin tan head.  Aroma pretty much as anticipated, whisky dominant with wood, roasted malt and chocolate notes. Started out sweetish with a solid roasted malt spine. The Whisky is pretty prevalent in the flavour, but there is enough there to prevent it from becoming saturating. Quite a nice warm almost comforting feel to this. Not much in the finish really. Im not the biggest  whisky aficionado, but I have certainly enjoyed Highland Park in the past, so I found this enjoyable on the whole and look forward to trying the older versions.

Bottle, Göteborg, Scotisch tasting 2010-02-06
AP: black beer brownish head AR/F:malt and whiskey, sweet vanilla fudge, a bit hollow vs the older ones, woody finish.

Thanks Beth101 for the bottle. Wish you were here to share it with me. Nice fruity aroma, quite a rich fell to it. Slight roasted malt hints. great deep black apperance with an off white head. Nice smooth texture. Fruity, malt and liquorice flavours. Nice texture. Very easy to drink for its strength. As it warms, chocolate and coffee start to come through. Very nice tasty ale.

Sept. 2007 vintage
Pours a pitch black with a thin head.  Aroma is sweet, with dark fruit, brown sugar, whiskey, and some wood notes.  The flavor is stronger on the whiskey and wood, and weaker on the sweetness, with some hoppy bitterness still after 2+ years.  The aroma and flavor together make for nice complexity when sipping.  The mouthfeel is a little lighter than expected from the color and style, but not unpleasant.  Overall, an impressive idea and a good beer.

Flaske: Mørkebrun næsten uigennemsigtig øl med et flot tæt lysebrunt skumhoved. Tovværk og en smule røg i duften sammen med en god gang chokolade. Smagen er igen utrolig velafbalanceret imellem en sød base af chokolade og en god del røg og tovværk. Superlækker øl, og en af de bedste whisky fadlagret øl jeg har smagt.

Bottle at home, 25th Jan 2010. Pours a velvety extremely dark brown with a small tan head. Releases a lovely woody, toffeeish whisky aroma when swirled. In the mouth you get dark chocolate, brown sugar, a hint of liquorice and just the right amount of whisky undertone. Its very balanced and very drinkable for a 8% beer. Very moreish aftertaste, I found myself wishing it came in bigger bottles!

An excellent dark fruit and roast malt nose leads inexorably into an almost purely whisky flavour. It is thick and smooth but terribly dry. Almost too dry and almost too whisky-y. You know what I mean.

Botlled from Systembolaget
Black with a medium, creamy beige head.
Dark and roasted. Pretty sweet. Light oak-notes with a vinous touch.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2011 2010-11-19, 8-5-8-4-16=41It pours a black color with glorious creamy brownish head. The aroma of the dark ale is complemented by tones of glueish alcohol, the whisky. It has a good body structure, yet the mouthfeel is not sticky; flavor of roasted malts, dark caramel, dark chocolate. The final shows at first elegant single malt whisky notes, then the roasted malts; quite dry. Probably one of the beers where the whisky has the best presence. Elegant and powerful.2009-04-23, bottle at Bishops Arms, Malmö, 7-4-8-3-15=37Black color; big head. Mild cask and smoke aroma, caramel. Medium body strength, quite smooth mouthfeel, with a good combination of caramel, chocolate malt and light smoke, a touch of whisky. In the end there is some more chocolate malt. Balanced, but sometimes a bit empty, mainly the final (weak), without vibes.

Near-opaque black. Chocolatey, roasty, nutty, smoky. Lots of dried fruit in there, a wood-savoury edge from the barrel, swirls of smoke. Very nice. I tried this alongside the whisky too to compare the two - that was a fun experiment!
Bottle. Black with small beige head. Dark roasted coffee and dark premium chocolate. Vanilla. Sweet liquorice. Dry after taste. Medium body. Overall a nice beer, maybe a bit too expensive.

Pours a blacky with a fading brown head. Nose is chocolate and toffe, faint sour notes, vanilla and some smoke and alcohol. The taste is packed with bitter licorice english style with brown sugar, roasted malty notes. Medium carbonation but a smooth  mouthfeel. Sweet finish with some alcohol and wood. Nice one. Like it

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. BB JULY 2012. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a fair mocha head.
  
Aroma:  A good dose of meaty/savouriness  cat food? - , some nice inky malts and phenolic smoke notes, deep black coffee and black chocolate, a touch of minty herbals and some leafy hops, slightly nutty.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderate-low effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much less of the meaty notes, more deep toffee, milk and dark chocolate, some licorice, black strap molasses, some peaty smoke, some wood, a bit of alcohol, fairly deep, dark and delicious; somewhat sweet with a malty-scotch finish than lingers, some bitterness.

Pretty nice stuff.  Not sure if Ill pay the premium for the 40 though...

Poured in a trappist.

AROMA chocolate, nuts, floral, butterscotch,
APPEARANCE  black, clear, minimal head dissappears quickly, brown foam
TASTE medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, complex taste sensation by balanced bitterness with sweetness
PALATE full body, thick feel, lively, long finish, very bitter

Definitely one to try, but quite a strong taste (peat!) from maturing in whisky barrels so maybe not one for everyone. Well balanced flavours and a very good palata.

0.33 bottle into trappist glass. Pours deep dark red-brown-black, no head just a little greyish froth.  Aroma is enticing malted and sweet, dark fruit and whisky smoke, peat.  Taste begins malty and sweet, with prune and raisen flavours then oaky and peat flavours, roasted coffee bitter finish with not much alcohol.  The whisky edge is quite subtle, but it does seem to go well with the beer.  Quite carbonated and moderately thick. Very nice.

Bottle: Black colour, nice brown creamy head. Aroma of citrus, dark choclate, caramel and  a nice coffee ending. Flavor is smouth creamy of caramel,choclate and coffee and a bit tar in the end. Medium body , and a nice long coffee finish.

Black beer with weak beige head. Aroma is strong, liquirice, peat, some sweetness, raisins. Flavour is similar than aroma, liquirice, smoke and nice sweetness. Ingredibly smooth and great to drink. Great balanced beer, strong roastiness with pleasant sweetness.

Pours pitch black with almost no head. The aroma is very dark malty at has clear whisky barrel notes. Dark roasted matls some smoked ham and salty licorice. Loads of dark fruits like raisins and dates. Some rummy caramel aromas too. Barrel conditioning results in oaky woodness and vanilla. A hint of alcohol int aroma tool. The taste is dryish, even chalky and wooden. Rummy caramel balances it well. Delicate whisky aromas and enjoyable roastedness in the finsih. Almost full bodied, a bit over carbonated.

Bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a small diminishing light beige head. Sweet and dry. Aromas of roasted malts with some whisky aromas. Hints of tar. Also hints of old wood. Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Sweet whisky flavoured finish. Hints of peated malts in the late finish.

Bottled 330ml from Quercus Brewery Shop, Kingsbridge, Devon. Black with tan head. Heavy, slightly thick, malty ale laced with malty whisky notes. Liquorice and tar flavours are most noticeable with a roast 7 ground coffee note behind. Strong alcohol note. Challenging.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2010 Oily, black color; aroma of tar, burned wood, smoke, roasted malt; medium to full bodied, low carbonation, smooth and slick: easy to drink; flavor adapting the nose, it´s full of tar, oak, liquorice and slightly smokey whisky in the finish.

330ml bottle from the LCBO. Sampled up against the 40, which narrowly won this battle. Pours black with lasting small tan head. Nose not as complex as the 40, but some nice scotch notes with smoke, and toffee. Taste is full bodied, lots of dark malt, chocolate, syrupy and smooth finish. Less scotch flavours than the 40, but a very nicely balanced beer.

Bottle 330  ml # 58102 (2009)  
Appearance:  deep dark brown appearance with excellent beige brown creamy crown. 5-        Nose:  soft, rich . sweet brown malts , barley with smooth character of whiskey barrel. Solid nose presented. 8+   Flavor/Palate :  mid full bodied, low carbonation. Ash with brown malt followed by dry alcohol. Lighter finish. All very smooth and dangerously drinkable. Solid sipper from Harviestoun.

Pours like it says, black oil, no head, almost no carbonation.  Nose of dark cherries, oak, chocolate.  Taste is strong oak, some smoke, with a bitter finish.  Decent but barrel seems to have overpowered it.

Bottle.

Pours black with a short lastign brown head.

Aroma of smoke, rosted malts and tarr.
Taste of rosted malts, wood and whiskey.

bottle from citywide.  pours a deep brown with a tan head.  Notes of whiskey, bread, chocolate,  smoke, tabacco, and moss.  mouthfeel is very thin.  I tend to really enjoy  bourbon stouts, but I dont particularly care for this whiskey flavor in the beer.

Bottled:Colour is very dark brown, could be mistaken for black. The mid sized head is pale brown. Aroma is seaweed, tar and smoke. Flavour is sweet tar, ash, smoke and liquorice. Well balanced and really good.

Pours a motor oil black with a thin tan head. Wow, the aroma is friggin wicked on this one, dark fruits, molasses, basement, oak, smoke, peat, campfire, bourbon, just like a full on running balls to the walls dropkick to the nostrils of aroma. The flavour is like wise, makes my mouth almost as equally happy as my nose, The flavour is malty chocolatey goodness upfront, molasses, some oakey dryness, smokiness, dark fruits, ends on a dry oak note. This beer really is something special, wish I could get my hands on the 40 year old, but it seems like the LCBO is being really skeevy with there stock.

Gorgeous aroma of fruit, soy sauce, oak, not a lot of whiskey, surprisingly.  The appearance is jet black, almost no head, just a thin tan foam ring. The flavor is soy, chocolate, fruit, nice.  The finish is where I notice the whiskey,  a nice lingering warming.  Medium to medium /thick, viscous, oily mouthfeel.  I thought it would be a little thicker.  Very good.

Purchased at the LCBO Rideau and King Edward (Ottawa), December 13, 2009, 330 ml bottle. Aroma of roasted malt and spicy scotch, notes of alcohol. Taste richly wooded, the scotch is verry malty, aftertaste of spice not too bitter. It was not given, but it was worth the price!

330 ml bottle fromt he LCBO. pours black with a tan head. salty barrel aroma with deep black malt layers. the flavour has everything you could ever ask for in a big black beer + smokey scotch + woody barrel. this is stupid easy to drink @ 8% abv. what an amazing brew, i cant wait to try the 40.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2009 330mL bottle from the Lickboe, acquired partly by luck, partly by my secretive beer hunting skills. Pours a deep dark brown with a medium khaki head. The aroma has some nice sharp yet still somehow subtle aspects of wisky, toffee, chocolate malt, dry chalk, coffee roast, smells pretty good. Flavour hits right away, huge sweet dark chocolate malt upfront with some nice woody dryness balancing it out. Very minor hint of scotch, and some chalk. Some interesting esters hiding in there too, oddly reminiscent of banana bread. Awesome fuller body from the oats. Surprisingly drinkable. More or less a stout though I guess its in a grey area. Awesome brew that Im glad to have had the opportunity to try (though it would be really nice if the LCBOs in a certain large city could quit hording all of this and the 40).

330 mL bottle.  (bottled July 2009).  Pours as black as can be with a small and rapidly dissipating brown head.  Aroma is sweet, with vanilla, oak, maraschino cherries and roast.  Flavour is smoke and roast up front, with chocolate and espresso in the end.  A touch of alcohol.  Almost gritty mouthfeel.  An excellent brew.

Aroma is of alcohol and roasted malt. Appearance is dark brown with a small off-white head. Taste is lots of wood, slight vanilla, roasted malts and some alcohol. Palate is a little thin with not much body. Overall not bad, but not worth the price.

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a dark black with small brown head.  Aroma of roast, whiskey, oak and toffee.  Flavour has strong whiskey character with roast and dark chocolate notes also very apparent as well as some toffee and oak.   Nice big body and very smooth mouthfeel, with light carbonation.  Unique and pretty nice.
0.33 l bottle from Alko. Sweet aroma with obvious whisky and oak with hints of coffee and licorice. Roasty and whiskeyish flavor with peat, licorice and charcoal. OK, A bit too oaky and peaty.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a black color with small brown head. Some lacing. Aroma is quite rich and inviting; burnt almonds, toffee, whisky, wood and roasted notes of dark chocolate. Theres also traces of vanilla. Flavour is sweet and toffee-ish. Theres lot of burnt almonds, chocolate, wood and whisky. A very light smokiness in the aftertaste. Medium to fullbodied. The mouthfeel is smooth and the carbonation is soft. A very nice beer.
Bottle at home. Black - brown head. Chocolate, smokey, whiskey, high malty, very smooth, high malty, oakey, wood, low carbonation, tar, tarmac, light burned. Very nice and drinkable.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 (br-btl bk/wh-lbl, Special 12 Reserve, bottles from sept 2007, drank may 2009 and sept 2011, $9, 80¢/oz)
